The answer to that illusion is simpler then that really... You are going way too far by exposing reality... On fact its called depth of field ! Close 1 eye and those illusions fails. The way the human work is by having 2 different field of visions. That gives us depth of field in our vision. Closing 1 eye stops this from happenning and you lose depth. Try it yourself its easy. Just closing 1 eye makes you almost unable te determine distances.

In the case of the mask... Its because it is symetrical. But you can still determine if its inside or not by the lighting which is inversed in the inside mask.

In the case of the ames room... Depth doesnt work. Because the room as been designed to screw that. So your brain uses perspective and assume what is closer is bigger. Its really just your brain going from 2D without depth of field to 3D using depth of field.

it initially looks like it stops for me, but once I fully understood what was happening with the Rubik's cube it (somewhat) broke the illusion for me as my brain adjusted to what I was actually looking at. Also, interestingly, the Ames room illusion has always been really fickle for me, I only seem to actually get it about a third of the time or so.

The way someone once explained it to me, the reason these types of illusions ultimately work usually has to do with the fact that we actually only have 2D vision, not 3D vision (if we had the latter, we'd be able to see every surface of every object from all angles simultaneously, which is obviously so different from how our vision actually works that it's not even really possible to imagine it accurately, but this is how a hypothetical 4D being would presumably see the world), but our brains are really good at combining 2D images from our retinas together to allow us to perceive depth (from a single directional vantage point, at least) and distance in 3D space. Our brains are so good at it, in fact, that they'll even do it with actual entirely 2D images like paintings, photos, etc. not to mention moving sequences of 2D images like films or animation. However, this means that our brain can also be somewhat easily "tricked" into perceiving illusionary depth in other situations where it seems to directly contradict other visual information we are receiving (because really, all depth perception is kind of an illusion for us in some sense), like when an object appears to move in a way which doesn't square with the way our brain wants to fit it into 3D space (which is sort of what's going on here).

The reason it varies somewhat is because different people's brains are essentially trained to intuit somewhat differently shaped 3D spaces (like the interior of a rectilinear building versus a rounded building, for instance) depending on what they get used to during the very early formative years of childhood when we're all first learning to understand this space which we can only directly perceive a little over 2 dimensions of at most. But even with these differences accounted for, no one can actually see in 3D, it's just not possible with the physics of how light moves through three spatial dimensions, and the physiology of how our eyes are able to obtain sensory information from visible light. Obviously, this last part is pretty much me restating what the video already says, but yeah, our limitations due to 2D vision are usually what's ultimately to blame for oddities like this.

The brain is trained to use certain cues to make a decision on where something is in space. As we grow up, we closely inspect things we see, we don't just look, but we touch. As we make a hypothesis on what we think is going on, then we inspect and evaluate what we see, until we know the truth, then we document that in our minds as truth. Then when we see similar components in other novel images, we reference these "truths" and apply them to the image, giving us a firm belief that we know what is going on with said image. Using tricks like forced perspective, versus contradictory shading, we can create a familiar image, one that appears to be the same as other images which have been thoroughly inspected in the past, that actual are composed of different qualities than the typical composition for said, and like said images. Thus resulting in an "optical illusion." I myself can consciously decide as to whether I choose to see the window oscillating or rotating, as I am consciously  aware of what optical qualities, versus what physical attributes, were actually used in composing the image. If I disacknowledge the fact that the window is trapezoidal, and view it as a rectangle, then my brain determines that the narrow end is narrow because of the belief that it is further, so I see it oscillate. Oppositionally, if I choose to acknowledged the window is a trapezoid, then I'm aware that the narrower end looks further away solely because of the fact that it is narrow, not actually further away, so I see it rotate.

Lol, just close 1 eye! It's your depth perception, and your brains normal way of processing the depth of either end that makes the smaller end always appear further away. Once you realize that the irregular shape is going to make your brain cancel forced perspective, and make the smaller end always look smaller, even when knowledge of forced perspective SHOULD have allowed you to notice the small end was closer, then the illusion occurs. Dr. Lisa Barrett's work in neuroscience shows that the typical brain develops in such as way as to make predictions based on as little data input as possible based on experience, rather than to consider the data and then react.  That is why these illusions are effective.  You are not seeing the world as it exists in front of you, you are seeing the world your brain predicts based on the smallest amount of data it can use to make a prediction.

So I had an interesting effect with the illusion. It worked well for me when it was a ruler in the window, or the rubik's cube, but when he was in it himself, his arms, legs and head created too many points of reference for my mind to track, and the illusion totally broke down.

Upon more thought it may also be possible that the reason the illusion breaks down for me when it is a person in the window and not a cube or a stick is because the person is asymmetrical. They have a head on one end and feet on the other. My mind could be using that information to correctly interpret the whole window as spinning.

Another possibility is that humans and the general shape of them are something we see regularly and are very good at identifying. It could be simply that my brain knows what a human looks like and is able to track that spinning, and correctly interprets the window as spinning with him.

Also when he showed the masks, the impression was obvious to me because it is darker. Less light goes into the impression so it will always appear darker than something that is sticking out.

Outstanding. Your closing point is timely, and wow.... relevant.  That also made me think about a perplexing mystery (one that you have probably covered). Specifically, the Monty Hall Problem. The fact that it confuses so many people is one thing. The paradox is how absolutely incredibly difficult it is to "teach" someone that the answer is correct.  ...especially when in reality, the problem is elementary school mathematics. (Which isn't to say that I understood it without great struggle). My theory has always been that there is something deeply rooted in our minds that expects binary decisions and observations - fight, or flight, light or dark, hot or cold, etc. That is purely speculation, of course. In any event, the study of the "rectangle familiar" reminded me of this.  Cheers, and thanks!!

This was an awesome presentation combining physical objects, perception and movement.  The section where you talk about what the "brain sees" vs. what you think you are looking at floored me.  The concept that the brain is always deciding, instant by instant, what it thinks you "should" be seeing by making comparisons with known objects and picking the one it thinks fits best is rather disconcerting.  Of course I see what I see, oops, that that little lump of matter in my head tells me what to see and what I am seeing is a bit frightening.

Very fascinating illusion. But there’s another factor that contributes to the illusion: the painting of the vertical  “surface” of each of the openings, which contributes to the 3D effect. But these are painted in such a way, identically on both sides, so that ONLY the long side of the trapezium could appear be to the front. If it were a true three dimensional figure the vertical inside edge of each opening that you are viewing would switch sides as the shape rotates showing its other side. But in the Ames illusions the painted openings are set up to make it appear that the long side of the trapezium is towards you, never the short side—so your brain thinks you’re seeing the same side all the time, meaning you’ll perceive the motion as oscillating, not rotating, thus adding to the anamorphic(?) effect. No wonder those babies thought there was something fishy going on!
The illusion is a product of prediction. As part of sanity, expectation influences our perception of space..

I’ve experienced a really strong illusion like this in my workshop. Two sheets of circle perforated metal, 8feet by 4feet on top of my bench and when I moved the top sheet across the lower sheet, the circles blended and confused my view so much that I felt like I was briefly falling. The effect was like closely looking at the very edge of a cosmic-sized single piece of perforated metal with a quick side to side view swooshing past my view.
It was very much like a third-eye experience during the brief illusion, it wasn’t allowing me to see the workbench or anything else.

Wow, this video really turned into some heavy anti-scientific propaganda there at the end. There is in fact such a thing as objective reality, even when we can't directly perceive or experience it. Did micro-organisms not exist before we were able to observe them with advanced lens technology? Of course they did.

This kind of "your truth is the only truth that matters" way of thinking is actually quite dangerous. When people have different analyses of material reality, it doesn't mean we should "be humble" and accept all the various opinions and conclusions as being correct in some way. It means there are contradictions that need further examination and clarification!

You can see clear examples of how dangerous such an idealist approach to truth is especially in politics. Look at climate change for example. It is demonstrably true that a societal model like capitalism (where production is dictated by private individuals according to profit potential rather than collectively according to human need in a sustainable fashion) will lead to catastrophic results, because infinite growth with finite resources is impossible. But the capitalist class continues to use their anti-scientific arguments to distract, mislead, misinform.. in essence to divide and hinder us from making a radical change based on the very real and overwhelming evidence at hand. No, something's wrong with your brain. We can clearly see the card rotating continuously.
It's flat, so it's two-dimensional. Following one edge makes it disappear behind the card as it completes a 360-degree arc, or orbit rather.
It's easy because one side of the trapezoid is longer than the other, so shading imaginary three-dimentionality around the openings doesn't help, unless you're highly gullible.
What you are trying to describe is perspective correction, such as what our binary vision uses to basically triangulate and estimate distance to an object. And as far as 90-degree angles are concerned, only places you'll find that is in artificial constructs such as man-made doors and room corners. The rest of nature is chaotic, and therefore this illusion doesn't work.

If we blink our eyes faster, we can see the rotational version.

Imagine an anticlockwise rotating point on a circle [sin(pi/4) == sin(3pi/4) == sin(9pi/4)]

There're definitely other factors but a possible analogous mental model is that - by blinking randomly our brain is forced to refresh its cache at a non-uniform rate.
doing this prevents the lazy part of our brain from interpolating information, hence we can distinguish if

1. we continued anticlockwise from (3pi/4) and travelled (6pi/4) to reach (9pi/4) [ROTATING]
OR
2. we switched to clockwise at (3pi/4) and travelled (pi/2) to reach (pi/4) [OSCILLATING]

This happens to me daily when rotating wireframe models using a 3D mouse. I rotate it one way but my brain steadfastly believes it is rotating the opposite. Our binocular vision is useless when inferring 3D space from a 2D screen, and we can easily be mislead when shadows and perspective cues are doctored as in the Ames window or absent as in orthographic wireframe CAD.

I recall the Donald Hebb rule:  Neurons that fire together wire together, if done repeatedly.  Over time, we see the world as it normally is, and our brains adjust accordingly, so that when we look at things at some unusual angle, we still see our normal world.  I like the Ames Window Illusion, because it's an opportunity to shake things up in our neural wiring.  I trust that, after several repetitions, I'll see that window rotating, instead of oscillating.

Thank you for this very thorough and understandable demonstration. I would like to add a bit of perspective (pun intended) from the lens angle. I am not a professional photographer, but I can tell you that perspective distortion grows the closer you are to an object, and the wider the lens angle. This is why a fisheye lens view looks so strange. Conversely, images shot through a telephoto lens have almost no perspective distortion. They wind up looking flat, and almost like an isometric drawing.

The Ames window illusion relies on your brain missing the minute size variations of the large and small ends of the trapezoid as they pass closer and farther from you, ignoring them in favor of the perspective cues it is getting from the trapezoid shape and the depth shading in the windows. Because of this, the illusion was much more effective when viewed from a distance in the African experiment. This is also why the large example you built was less effective (in addition to the thickness you mentioned) because it is difficult to back away from it indoors. This also suggests a version of the illusion, if viewed across the solar system via telescope, which is essentially indistinguishable from reality.

Love the conclusion - far too many people are overconfident in their ability to reason and make conclusion on the limited data they have.

The optic nerve, I think, is responsible for building the world you live in. It does NOT construct an accurate view of the world (This has been shown to be damaging to an organism, ironically!) and merely builds up a 3D environment based on its best interpretations of past experiences.

To imagine the human mind "sees" the world as it truly exists in all circumstances is absurd, and why optical illusions work so well.

Often your optic nerve will "see" something it can't interpret fast enough, and so that location isn't completed by the process, and so you get a functional "hole" in your visual field until you direct enough focus on it, and change your perspective sufficiently to decide what you're looking at.

It's also why we get so many reports of alien UFOs: Human inability to properly create a fully accurate world view at all times.

As a skydiver I learned that our eyes have basically 3 modes of operation.  0 to about 18" our brain determines distance by how much the eyes physically cross/uncross.  After this, and out to about 4,000 feet our brain determines distance via parallax.  Past this distance the brain cannot really tell distance.  The illusion forces the eye to see a false parallax - hence the illusion.  I am just glad we don't have 3,000 foot tall Ames objects!

All I know is that it fixes it a bit when I watch the corner going around. This reminds me a bit of the dancing ballerina illusion. If you've never seen that, it's a VERY similar one, but a silhouette of a ballerina spinning. The thing is, it can do weird things with your mind, such as even changing direction of rotation. And, there's some evidence it does so based on which side of your brain is most active. Like there was a YouTube video on this where they snuck in a picture of a flock of birds flying to the side of it or other images of order (which activate the left brain) and it would spin one way, while when they put more artistic images into frame (activating the viewer's right brain), it would spin the other way. The general conclusion I got at the time was that the way it appeared to spin was entirely dependent on which side of one's brain was dominant, BUT, that the side of your brain that is dominant (for the purposes of the perception) CAN CHANGE. So even a left brain dominant, right handed person can be made to be TEMPORARILY right brain dominant based on stimuli AND that this stimuli alters PERCEPTION ITSELF.

I love the "Science - like magic but real" t-shirt. One reason why I never got the hang of magic in fiction (and I've only been able to articulate it for the last 10 years or so) was how it had the feeling of a dirty trick designed to shamelessly hide all the irreducible complexity behind a spell or symbol. So you want to influence someone's behavior? Great, what's the mechanism of this influence, what's the specification language, who or what is mediating? Magic! So you want a genie to build a palace for you? Great, which of the myriads of designs you want, which of the near infinite wealth of details should be there, where do find building material? Magic! However I tried to come up with a hypothetical theory of magic (demons, energy manipulation, hacking the code of the universe) it either came out nonsensical, or required you to put in the missing complexity by hand anyway. I'm done ranting about magic, but my negative sentiment only makes me like that t-shirt more. And Derek, I hope you'll keep making Veritasium what it is until the singularity and beyond, because this truly is a bright and hopeful spot in our part of the universe! Live long and prosper!

Hahahah - don't you know this yet?
The speed of light is NOT consistent & thus is NOT always the same speed.

IT is ONLY a certain speed - going away from whatever created the light.
If a light is shone on a mirror such that it bounces off - at say 90 degrees (from a 45 degree angle mirror)
The speed of light aimed towards the mirror - is of course - travelling at the speed of light.
The bounced light heading off at 90 degrees - is also heading off, at the speed of light FROM ONLY THE MIRROR,
YET if seen from where the light came from originally - it will now only be doing ?
Merely about two thirds of the original speed, as it would be travelling across the angle - not the whole distance - if "seen" to be travelling - from it's original source.

Also - if one is TRAVELLING - at high speed (a lot faster than a cop will allow) - such as in a fighter jet - that is approaching the speed of sound..?

ANY LIGHT- shone at the jet - from behind it - appears to be coming at the jet - at a speed about the same SLOWER SPEED
As the speed of sound difference to the speed of light. ie: a lot slower and will take a long time to "light up" the jet - which by then will be a long way away.
As - the light reflected off the jet - will also take longer to travel back the greater distance - to it's source - for anyone holding the torch - to "see" the jet in the light beam !!!

In other words - the light trying to catch the jet - will take a LONG TIME.
Whereas if a light is SHONE - to the front of a jet - going at or near the speed of sound.
Whatever shone that light will see the reflected light a LOT QUICKER than anyone shining a light from behind.
Yet
The ground speed of that beam of light - will in fact be travelling at the speed of sound FASTER than a light being shone from behind the jet - from a ground source.
ie:
ADD the speed of the jet (itself travelling at or near to - the speed of sound) onto the jet's speed of light "light beam" which will be emitted to the front of the jet - at the speed of light away from the jet
And you will have a beam of light (in respect to the ground) travelling almost twice the speed of light.


But - if a light is shone out the rear of that same jet - towards whatever is being shone at it, the two lights will "cross" about where the jet left the airport - not at either the jet's position nor the ground source position of the other light.

Thus each is travelling at twice it's own speed - (in respect to each light beam) if seen from the front tip - of either light.

Otherwise - what point would there be - to having headlights on a car - if the car (say travelling at the speed of light) - couldn't get the light to come out of the headlamp unit - to light up the road - half a mile ahead of the speeding vehicle.?

comment_text: The host's proposal that we should look at our "certain" conclusions with more "humility" is the classic statement of an induct. That is, there are always people who say, "logic can't always solve things; there will always be exceptions. Give us more data." Except that the exceptions should be thought of as systemic, rather than asystemic. These systemic things that appear non-systemic may be functions that only become functive over time. You can think of them as the "long tail" of probabilistic reality. The universe doesn't care that we like to go where "most" observations seem to occur; the "least" observations have as much validity. It's all a matter of perspective.

I have a book, published in 1952 by the Princeton University Press, entitled The Ames Demonstrations in Perception.  It covers many illusions, including "The Distorted Room Demonstrations" and the "Rotating Trapezoid."  My Dad (who went to Princeton and worked for the Press at the time) showed me the book when I was in grade school and it really got me interested in depth perception.  We made one of those rooms (on a much smaller scale! 😀) out of cardboard as a diorama for a school project. ❤️

The Ames Window is not as complicated as you and others explained. It is just a simple expectation issue. The illusion is quite trivial: due to the trapezoid shape of that maximum front view, the instinct is tricked to believe that it is not the view of the maximum size of the front view, and thus expect that the width of the window will continue to increase as the rotation continues which is what exactly would happen to a rectangular window....but instead they see the width reduces, so the intuition tells us that the window is oscillating backwards...

not because it's an ad - and even not because the sponsor demands it (although rather fair to you to have you just put it at the end)
my issue with vpn sponsors in more general is their blatant false advertisement - in fact, "security for the end user" can't be more from the truth as many of the services either have their hq in a country which demands backdoors and logging an such - or hosting servers in such countries
so there's no hiding against the authorities - it's just plain another 2000s dotcom bubble waiting to rupture in a big bang
I once had a short two e-mail conversation with Tom Scott (yes, THE Tome Scott) about his video about 2FA pointing out some "issues" - and, fun fact, he agreed with my "critics", but we both also agreed upon him creating a technical 100% correct video vs him creating a video his audience can "digest" - so he cut a few corners here and there
so - TLDR: what's my issue with VPN? it's their complete nonesense about rising fear in you about danger that someone in a public hotspot could steal your credit card or could read your mails - that's just outright WRONG! - there's just no way such attack would work with a proper TLS secured site - an attacker trying to fool you it's computer is the real gmail? yea, good luck with that - IF someone would have that power we could throw out pretty much any technology that relies on either the RSA problem or the DH problem - your system would noticed that you're NOT on the real gmail but rather on some faked imitation of it ... using a VPN adds exactly ZERO additional security to it - in fact: it even has the potential to LOWER it - as it could sent you manipulated data cause it got some fishy certificate sponsored by some three-letter-authority ... that's the kind of risk you put yourself into when "trusting" a vpn service to "do no evil" instead of just use a public network and use simple tls to connect to the requested service directly
also: using a distributed network to mimic a wrong location could also risk legal issues back to you not just cause you violate most terms of use/service (have a look at the details - pretty much any service denies you to use such service to mock your location) - but use such tech can (and I would guess actually IS) illegal in some areas ...
so - it's your choice - spent that 10 bucks a month for all that blatant false security - or just save it and use the internet with all its reliable security in place ... may you have enough time when you're on the other side of the bars ...

Nonsense.  The problem with the "perspective" theory, is that in every example you gave, one of the possibilities could be confirmed, even if just theoretically, which would leave the rest of them as "incorrect".  The idea of perspective is important, and quite often misunderstandings exist between two people who are both incorrect in their assessment.  That said, it doesn't matter how vehemently two misguided perspectives make their case, there is still an actual reality out there to be discovered.  This is why it is, in my opinion, less important to immediately grant any default level of legitimacy to every perspective, and to instead operate under the old adage, "don't hold strong opinions about things you don't understand."

What I find odd about this particular perspective illusion is that I actually find it much more difficult to parse the movement as a full rotation when an additional object is added. For example, when he is demonstrating with the small model, it doesn't look like oscillation to me at all, until he adds the Rubik's Cube. I'm guessing this is because I'm fairly well attuned to small visual cues that help my brain disregard the misleading factors of disproportionate sides and shading, but when another object is added, it distracts my vision from those small cues, thus making it more difficult to process the actual motion.

I came to the belief a long time ago, that reality is a perception. The things you experience may not be real, but they are still what you experience, and are therefore real. You can think of it as every person having their own 'local reality'. Most people have very little understanding of how a computer works. They push the button, and it starts. But a skilled technician can explain in thorough detail the exact processes that take place in order to create that 'observed reality'. Just because the average person doesn't know all of these things that take place, does not take away from their experience. After all the end result was the same for both the uninformed, and the informed: the computer turned on. What this means is that two people can watch and participate in the exact same thing, yet have completely different opinions and beliefs about it. Not because one is simply being stubborn or confrontational (although that may be the case in some instances), but because on a very deep level in their minds, they experienced something completely different from the other person, despite the event being the exact same for both people.

I think your final conclusion is pure bunk. An Illusion is not reality. We may perceive different things from the same data, but only ONE conclusion is actually correct, the other has been tricked.

The Ames Window APPEARS to be oscillating. It is NOT. It is in fact rotating. The reason so many people come to different conclusions from the same data today is because many have been taken in by popular "illusions".

Take the Coronavirus pandemic. Did it originate in a Lab, or a wet market? Do masks protect you, or are they basically security theater? Do the lockdowns actually save lives, or do they simply slow the spread of the virus? Is Dr. Fauci telling the truth, or was he telling the truth?

These things cannot be simultaneously true, one is wrong and the other is right, though it seems that every day now what the media and politicians tell us is the correct answer is oscillating back and forth...

I can say, "crime is down in Portland after defunding the police, here look at these statistics." Nevermind that violent crimes and murders are up 800%...

You cannot say that all perspectives are equally valid. The entire lesson this video teaches is that you can be tricked into believing anything, given the right framing...

What you said at the end is probably right, but it's worth adding:
Humility and certainty are not opposites. You DO want to have humility, but you also want certainty. in the areas where it's possible. You also want knowledge even without certainty (which is probably 99% of human life: knowledge without certainty). What you DON'T want is hubris. You also don't want irrationality or non-sequiturs. The result of discovering optical illusions can't be pure skepticism, if that was true, then you wouldn't know there was an illusion. What it should do is make us realize that we need to observe more, especially from multiple perspectives (and the goal is all perspectives). And when you can't, take note of that and adjust your level of certainty.

There's nothing wrong with skepticism and uncertainty, but it's not the goal, it's the motivator to get us to the goal.

The important aspect of this illusion is, as you pointed out, perspective. Everything is bent due to this effect. It is also why the moon never moves across the field of view when driving on a straight length of highway, whereas mountains in the distance do very slightly, and the foreground even faster. We are just traversing the same number of miles on the surface of the moon as we are on its planet, but the moon is so large, we cannot even mark the length of our travel (65 miles) in an hour, because it is zoomed down so small.

The interesting parallel here, is the concept of projection. Whereby you get a trapezoid if you have a square framed image projected on a planar surface that is not normal (perpendicular) to the optical axis of the projection (hence trapezoidal adjustment on projectors). Moreover, projection of matrices in mathematics apply here,. Just as your Ames room projects points along the lines of perspective onto a planar surface that is not normal to the z axis of the room, you can see that a cube casts a shadow of several different polygons depending upon the 3D position in space of the cube with respect to the parallel lines of the light from the sun (and again, the sun being nearly a million miles in diameter, is casting its light onto the relatively tiny Earth (8k miles in diameter) such that their radial separation (due to a point source of that diameter) is very small, thus practically parallel light rather than light from a light bulb, which is in contrast, a point source of light, thus with large radii meaning a cone of light emanating from it).

So goes the concept of unfolding a 3D object into 2D, like the six squares forming a cross, which can be folded into a 3rd dimension and becoming a cube. Add a dimension to the problem, and 6 cubes become a 3D unfolded version of a 4D object. If you could fold the unfolded 3D tesseract into the 4th dimension, you would have 6 cubes sharing the same 3D space, or, superpositioning through th 4th dimension, If you put a dot on one of the unfolded cube walls, then fold it into the 4th dimension, that dot would exist in one wall of all 6 cubes. That dot would have 6 existences, or instances, yet still be the original singular dot, existing in 6 different places, each simply a different perspective of the same 4D space, but we can only perceive them as being stacked ontop of each other, because we cannot fathom a 4th physical dimension.

The Ames window is doing the same thing with a 2D projection of a 3D object, and when you put a 3D object onto that 2D rotating object, then the 3D object offers a 3rd extra dimension for your brain to process, which is why it is clearly rotating around the 2D trapezoidal abnormal perspective 2D object.

Effectively, without shading, you lose the 3rd dimension when a 2D drawing of a 3D object is viewed; that is the whole point -- projection loses dimensional information. Shading, though still 2D, can provide the 3rd dimension (Z axis) indirectly, by inserting a new perspective -- a light source, and it works because that light source, exists in a 3rd dimension, and makes the entire picture as projection of that perspective, through the 2D projection of that light source, only by putting dark shadows where the 3rd dimension would cast them, It is indirectly creating a 3rd dimension. Without this, a staircase can be inverted in your mind.

So perhaps in the end, we see that perception of reality can be easily clarified if we understand perspectives, and, if only we could fathom the 4th, 5th and other dimensions -- if a 2D object can fool us into believing there is or isn;t a 3rd dimension, then quantum mechanics, double slit experiment, quantum erasure experiment, etc., might all have an obvious answer if the correct dimensional information were filled-in to our perspective. Just a thought,.

I remember when growing up seeing the Ames illusion represented in a book, (love those TIME LIFE books).  Over my lifetime I have come to believe that this illusion arises from the evolutionary pressures during human development, to discern the location and distance and directional movement of predators and prey in dim lighting.   Many factors play a near simultaneous role in predator prey interactions, but there seems to be a priority of importance. Animals seem to be first oriented to any movement which represents a change in the instantaneous static picture they have of their surroundings.  Then they are using static lighting and shapes to discern predators (or prey) to tell them what is present (hence the value of camouflage).  The next priority involving more sophisticated brain function and probably later in evolutionary terms would seem to be trying to interpret the intent or meaning of the animals motion.  The more primitive yet preeminent need to rely on shape and shade to our survival is demonstrating its evolutionary priority when we are faced with these types of illusion.

There is an example of anamorphic art in the Naval Aviation Museum at Naval Air Station Pensacola in Florida. There is a 10 foot wide painting from the point of view of a plane coming in for a landing on an old carrier. The faces are actually a extremely easy case to determine depth, inpression has a receeding jawline due to the blocked off decline of the chin, so it easy easy to determine depth based on the position of the chin, aswell as the inverted shadows caused by light. Beating this illusion is no different, Looking through the illusion and focusing on what information can continue to be seen within/around it, how much of the background perception is blocked, abnormal interactions with light, and most importantly shifting "depth" of the object itself particularly when it reached a parallel position to the viewer losing all depth. As for the skull painting. I simply see a skewed but clearly skewed skull at all angles from the start, but I suppose 2 conflicting inputs from your eyes may result in a distorted blur to some... Akin to the 3d image's that require 2 crossing points of view aimed behind the image to see , which I simply can not at all.

When your brain has been trained to utilize all this consistently reliable information RATHER than rely heavily on the use of the 2 (trained but still ultimately random) crossing points of view to gain a false estimated perception of depth which is technically an illusion itself, you can easily see through these illusions attempting to exploit said interaction. This is actually why humans have a superior depth perception with one eye closed, however in general practices the offset of pov will leave most people disoriented in normal activity. But when orienting a object which you can center at the eye, that is no longer a issue. This is why shooters are more accurate with one eye in most cases.

comment_text:
Neuroscience suggests something more startling: 👇👇👇
This processing happens ABOVE your level of consciousness.
The brain decides what to show you.

The actual images are correctly processed on the "Center-Surround" receptors of the retina.
Logic tree of these receptors is as follows:
(On/Off = Off/On = ON)
(On/On= Off/Off= OFF).

It's after this basic processing that the brain compares it's results to statistical likelihood of previous experiences. That's why children must develop the ability to do this, and aren't born with it: There is no statistical data to draw from.

The brain makes many guesses when 2 equivalent possibilities exist. (The LGN is at play here also.) It's the ambiguity well after processing that gets resolved here. A super-conscious selection among choices. (We know this is the case, because "color" is a component of this particular illusion, and is processed very late in the system, at V4).

All evidence points towards a Super-Consciousness making these decisions.

For one: the electrical impulses of nerves have been measured, and found that decisions at the neuron level are made before your conscious mind is aware of them. (Voxel cell bundling, like 3D pixels, make decisions as groups).

All of the basic shapes and orientations are processed in layers, starting with simple constructs and adding texture, hue, and color afterwards. (V1-V2-V3-V4, in the occipital lobe).

It's only after the brain is faced with a statistical anomaly, that it compares the data to statistical history, and resolves the conflict.

This mechanism is present in illusions of this type. With practice, the illusions can be chosen between. This is essentially your brain asking for statistical updates from your satisfaction with your experience (effectively a comment card).

So the big news here isn't the illusion, it's that humans have a Super-Consciousness. (At least that's the part that has changed my understanding of "Reality". But don't worry, you get used to it... Sort of 🤔)

Like Standard Quantum Mechanics and the Grand Unified Theory-Classical Physics can interpret the same farfield pattern of the 2 slit experiment using very different models of the particles involved, the photon, electron or neutron. SQM uses waves to do this but GUT-CP does not even have waves in that theory, as real entities. The waves under SQM have been accepted for so long, that they have come to be viewed as being necessarily or inevitably existing as an aspect of particles and therefore that it is only by using particles having a wave aspect that this experiment and all other experiments can be explained. It seem to be such an anathema, that the existence of waves does seems to have any not need to even enter such explanations.
The reason behind this attitude, of deep acceptance of waves, where there are none, is the very long and deeply ingrained view of waves that has come to be held by those studying quantum mechanics. To even propose this concept, of waves not even existing anywhere, is not only extremely foreign to QM physicist, but it paints a very threatening picture of what it would mean, if that were true. So much so that, such a thought never, ever ,enters into considerations towards explaining the outcome of any experiment or how some quantum scale phenomenon works. Because if true, practically all or almost all work done in QM, would be invalidated. That end point is immediately taken as being too much to accept or absurd to even be contemplated. What I love about this illusion is that I can kind of "bypass the illusion" by imagining that the window is still moving in the same direction (as it actually is), but a gut part of me is simultaneously falling for the illusion. I've never felt more split brained lol. But I think that's actually a significant, profound example of how, sometimes, creating a illusion can counter another illusion. When I was a kid I was running in a field at night, looked up and realised that I'd always been seeing the night sky as a "painted ceiling"; because this time I "saw" the depth of the stars. I wasn't actually seeing it, of course; but something about the movement of my surroundings against the sky helped my brain "click" and I saw what I intellectually understood, but had never actually seen before. It's weird to think that a counter illusion might be your best bet at seeing something for what it is

I love MC Escher and the Penrose Stairs, there is a carpentry challenge.  As an entomologist I see visual illusion phenomena employed by insects, without getting into natural selection or evolution.  Butterflies are very good at this, ants that present as spiders to potential predators that may be poisonous to ingest.  But what has me intrigued if not brain blocked is the use of prisms in the insect and invertebrate world, specifically hummingbirds who can change appearance to court or hide.  If you have not examined this topic previously, I would love to see one of your breakdowns on the topic.  It is just as fascinating as the Ames window illusion, possibly even more complex to simplify.  Another topic more relevant today, since you mentioned the assumed speed of light as a constant when we now know the "laws of nature" are more like guidelines,  is how specific light waves eg UV-C in the 254nm range and 03 can sanitize surfaces and the kill airborne pathogens.    Thanks for all the hard work!

Your point about how scientific theories are not always 100% certain demonstrates the beauty of science, in my eye. A theory almost acts as a placeholder for how the world is understood until more data is available that can make our understanding more accurate/useful. In that sense, we are always working with placeholders until we make the next breakthrough that lets us set a new placeholder.

I'm really curious what focal length you shot the rotation video through, and if you found that looking at it through a wide[r] angle lens makes it easier to tell which end of the rectangle is closer to you as it spins, or if the illusion persists even then. I'm guessing that standing closer while looking through a wide angle lens, it'd be easier to tell the difference in height of each end when that end is closer to you as compared to when it is farther away, potentially making it easier to sort out - but I'd love to be proven wrong about that. This would track with the results of the study done in South Africa that you mentioned in the video - when they stood farther away, it became more difficult to recognize the rotation. The longer the focal length of the lens you look through, the more the difference in size between foreground and background becomes diminished, right..? So I'd think that the intensity of this illusion would be most pronounced when looking through a relatively long focal length lens. But just like Maker's Muse, I was surprised by how much the rubik's cube broke my brain. So who knows if the focal length could even make enough difference to overcome the illusion? ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

I studied engineering in London in the 1950s. The final year comprised 4 English and 10 West Africans. In examinations the West Africans would usually beat the English. We reckonned the Africans were more academically-minded because they had been selected in their countries by a different process. (Possibly they were on the wrong course, or else we were!). But there was one subject at which they were all hopeless, and that was Engineering Drawing. Especially they all had immense problems understanding *isometric projections*.

For example, looking at a dawing of a cube as seen from one of its corners, the English could immediately perceive that it represented a three-dimensional object. But the West Africans would often see only three parallelograms. I presume that cultural differences affected perception.

FFS! Stop with the flat Earth-level theories of multiple directional light speeds!
Test it yourself! fix a light source of specified material and intensity on a ring so it can be rotated around the point of measurement of the light's wavelength.
Test it in one position. Rotate the light to 180 degrees from the measuring point and test again.
If... light traveled at varying speeds based on the direction it was moving, the resulting wavelength would scale up or down in accordance with that direction of travel, and the disparity in rates could easily be determined.

But that doesn't happen. The wavelength remains identical in every direction.

The shape and lighting are not the only keys to the illusion.  But it is also the isolation of the elements (nothing to provide the benchmark of perception).  Also, it is a stylized shape devoid of all characteristics except 3 (shape and two colors. Nothing recognizable that requires 3 dimensions)  Also, the perspective (straight on) provides only one angle (static perception without the help of triangulation which advances truth (which also happens to be the scriptural standard for condemning a man in a crime (upon 2-3 witnesses))). Also, the clip is short (not enough time to train the eye and see past the illusion).  And finally, hyper focus on the object (further reducing overall visual cues that can be obtain through peripheral vision.  I'd say I just cracked the code of programing and deprogramming of the masses.  Though we should be careful of our certainties, we will in the end be accountable for what we believe.  The shaddow and angle of the ruler do help.  And although the paint is flat and not glossy, there are additional visual clues through light reflecting bright spots.  If you can see through part of the illusion, you at least have got yourself a foothold.  The time for lazy thinking is over.  These concepts can easily be applied to to a divide and conquer agenda.

Try some human voice illusions:  Have a "head in a box" look like it says one word while making the sound speaker actually say another word.  A number of combinations give very odd results.  In fact, in a video I saw years ago, the head's mouth looked like it said an entire nonsense phrase while another, totally different nonsense phrase came from the sound speakers.  If you closed your eyes, the sound nonsense phrase was heard by you, but if you looked at the moving mouth of the head in the box, I distinctly heard, "Hello, how are you?" IN PERFECT ENGLISH!!!  Somehow, the two nonsense phrases, one being mouthed and seen by your eyes and the other being heard by your ears at the same time, acted like the mixer tube in an old AM radio and out came the "IF" signal  (changed to English) that was riding on the radio's "carrier wave".  This would be the ULTIMATE stealth encrypted message system.  Only a person looking at the correct talking head and listening to the message being sent in seemingly totally different words on a telephone or radio or video would hear the true message with no "secret decoder ring" needed at all!  It also shows that our brains work in VERY, VERY STRANGE WAYS, far beyond just optical illusions...

«The truth is there are many circumstances in which the same data could come from very different external realities.»

One example where this happens and needs to be explicitly addressed by iterative computational techniques, experimental techniques and statistical modelling is the determination of crystal structures through diffraction studies (such as determining the shape of a protein via x-ray crystallography).

When one points a beam of x-rays at a crystalline sample one does not get a photograph of the repeating unit in the crystal (which is really the end goal when performing such a study —that is, this is what we really want to know). Instead, one gets a series of dots in a radially symmetrical pattern which are formed when periodically arranged electron dense areas deviate the x-ray beam (known as diffraction) in predictable ways. The pattern will also change in a particular way depending on the angle of incidence upon the crystalline sample. The information the crystallographer has at the end of the process of data acquisition is the location of the dots & the intensity of the dots as the crystal is rotated in space.

There also exists another needed parameter which is not directly experimentally accessible to the crystallographer which is called theta. The goal of the crystallographer is to determine what kind of a repeating arrangement will produce a particular pattern. The difficulty here is that different thetas would imply different repeating electron density arrangements.

As a result, one could think of the job of the crystallographer as using a set of tools at their disposal to determine the correct theta through which to interpret the experimental data. This is usually not trivial.

Best ride at the old fairground when I was a kid - the Haunted Swing! A large box that rotated around the centres of two opposite walls using large bearings and a tube steel 'swing seat' in the middle of the room. Inside the box was made to look like a real room with furnishings, a window with painted view, and of course the door where you entered 'ride' - about 6 people could sit on the swing. The door was closed. Then the swing slowly went back and forth. After about 2 mins the room started to rotate slowly forward ie the ceiling came down in front of you. Ok you knew what was going on. The room continued spinning at same rate. No problem. The after about4 mins, the room stops rotating and then spins backwards, all the time the swing is still going back and forth. At this point your mind cannot separate which movement is which. Where are you in the swing cycle? Which way is up or down? Basically your mind gets screwed and its a really weird and nauseating feeling that also affects your stomach. It should be noted that several mop and buckets where kept outside the ride and the whole room smelt a little bit like sick and disinfectant lol!

This isn't an illusion, it's a camera trick. When you remove depth information by filming the thing in 2D, and then also make sure no shadows are visible in the shot (careful lighting and a solid, dark background), it's impossible to tell whether one end is moving toward you or away from you -- even robots would make the same "mistake".

The effect is based on the loss of depth information when viewed on a 2D screen. Being deprived this information, the brain has to reconstruct it using the secondary hints available like shapes and lighting - and you noticed that those properties are distorted on purpose. Thus, the brain fails to properly infer the motion path of the window frame, whereas the motion path of un-distorted human body is projected correctly. This eventually results in the illusion of one passing through the other. Needless to say, this only works when watched on the screen; watching it in real life (or 3D screen) does not result in the illusion because the loss of information does not occur.

It's interesting that even such an illusion brings us to very different conclusions:
Derek: The same rotating object is seen as rotating by some and oscillating by most. And so many unanswered scientific questions present us with the same dilemma. Therefore, we should be humble about the knowledge we have.
Me: Precisely this example shows that despite what we might believe to be true, there is just a single truth about this object - it's rotating, even though my brain can't accept it. So, let's base our beliefs solely on science, since it's the only thing capable of showing us the truth. It doesn't matter if I or everyone thinks the window is oscillating. It's rotating and our believing otherwise won't change the reality. So, let's only be humble about the areas in which science is still unsure what is true.

My brain got "tricked" in a funny way, and I have only told a few people. With all the comments on here already, Veritasium might not read this one but oh well. Anyway, it was a few years ago during a quite hot summer in Texas. Are their any other kind? This was even more so, but that's not part of the story, I'm pretty sure.
I was out in my backyard, putting out food and water for my cats during the middle of the afternoon. The sky was very hazy with high clouds, cirrus and altocirrus, and they are part of the story.
I wasn't particularly paying attention to the clouds, mostly I wanted to get the animals fed and watered and go back in the house. With temps over 100degrees I wasn't thinking about much else. But I bent over to put water in a bowl, and out of the corner of my eye, for just a second, my brain glimpsed something!!
The high clouds, for those of you who know, can create a phenom known as sundogs, bright spots of reflection determined by the angle of the sun to the observer, etc. etc.
Well I was just in the right place at the right time. It's not like I'd never seen sun dogs! They are a wonderful atmospheric phenomenon. But at that instant, my brain was somewhere else, and I, being a lifelong astronomy and sci-fi reader got lost in my head a little bit. My brain knew where the sun was, it was beating down overhead, but the sundog didn't quite register as a sundog instantly because I was distracted. The first thing that came up in my list of brain definition of a second bright light in the sky like that was "second sun!!" So for just an instant I was living on a binary sun planet!! HAHAHA
It was wild there in my world, but it didn't last long. A second, really less I think, later, my brain realized I was not on some distant world far away from where it had always been.
Still on planet earth with one sun! haha

This is a good example of how human experience & meaning take place in a different realm than science or technology.  It also explains why, for over half a century, discussions between physicists have sounded like theological debates.

At 13:43 Derek says, "The truth is, there are many circumstances in which the same data could come from very different external realities", but I don't think that's "the truth".

While we might just be dealing with differences in nomenclature, I fundamentally disagree with the concept of multiple realities coexisting. I contend there is just ONE (1) external reality we all share, not many. Our perceptions of reality may differ, but that doesn't mean external reality itself is different for each of us. Things get complicated when considering the science of relativity, but at human scale, these differences are undetectable. Unless and until someone shows that there ARE different realities that coexist, I reject the notion of multiple realities.

(For Schrodinger's Cat... say you line up 100 people, and each one opens the box in turn, without telling the others what they have observed, then each person simultaneously checks a box, DEAD or ALIVE... There was a place called Mystery Hill in northern Ohio which always perplexed me as a kid. Even then, I figured it was in principle like an Ames Room, but they incorporated gravity into the illusion. As you went from room to room, the gravity shifted increasingly toward the opposite side of the room. Tourists walked in at the northeast corner of the building (through the north wall) walked along a path defined by a rail to the southeast corner, where they made a 90 degree turn. The rest of the tour, they were on the south side of the building walking west. The doors they walked through were right next to that southern wall. In each room, the illusion was that gravity was pulling you more and more northward rather than downward--but also that the rooms were each cubes (or at least had 90 degree angles at every edge). The tour guides did things like make water appear to run uphill in one room and having a tourist defy gravity by sitting in an ordinary chair which had its back legs placed on a 2x4 nailed to the north wall, while the front legs hung out in midair (I was the volunteer on our trip, and I even stumbled against the gravity on my trip back to the south wall).
Obviously, the trick was that each room in the building was progressively more and more inclined so that the north was lower than the south end. I understood that even at age 7. But what flummoxed me was how they concealed it. It wasn't difficult to SEE from one room into the next, to compare the floor of the last room to that of the next. And I couldn't see any change in pitch. Nor could I see anything to indicate that the floor in any room was curved or warped. I suspected that there was some kind of Ames illusion in play, but I couldn't tell HOW it was being employed.

And yeah, this optical illusion really baffled me as even knowing what is really happening my brain simply refuses to accept the truth. Now I do have a thing for these optical tricks myself, and I am for that reason a very big admirer of the Dutch graphic artist M.C. Escher. I inherited a book with most of his work when my grandfather passed away, and although the book is really in an awful state (I know a place where I can give that book some "treatment" but it has to wait until the COVID19 misery is over), the content in it is still looking good, and really no matter how many times I keep browsing through that book the more I am amazed by the way he could create things that are physically impossible, but which work in a drawing (next to the other kind of graphic effects he managed to work with making things perfectly go over in each other). It appears Escher himself always refused to acknowledge there was any science or mathematics in his work.... Did you ever do a video on how Escher's "fake reality" pictures manage to work out giving us a thing we know is physically impossible, and yet they work, and sometimes we know the picture cannot be, but cannot explain why it cannot be... When it comes to optical illusions, this could be a nice subject. ;)

The reason why more people saw oscillation with one eye closed is because it is much harder for brain to figure out distance to edges of an object with just one eye. This is why people have 2 eyes - to help brain better understand what is the distance to the observed object. This is also why that particular illusion looks much cooler when it is recorded with non-3d camera and/or watched on 2d display compared to when the same illusion is observed in real life.

I think the problem is that there is objective truth and hypothetical situations. To say that perspective (subjective truth) opens the door to dismantle the objective truth, is a mistake. We know what is really going on with the window. That is objective truth in the face of our perspective. The objective truth can be found, the window is doing SOMETHING objectively, the light moving is doing something objectively. The rotation of the sun or earth is doing something objectively. Our perspective informs our understanding, but only gets us closer to the objective. To throw our hands up and say, "well, we can never really know," is the worst kind of argument. I personally believe it's more important to take a stance on the objective and adjust as any new information becomes available. Which takes humility and is hard.

Glad to see you moving into perceptual phenomenon. There is a common fallacy that the wavelength (or frequency) of electromagnetic radiation determines the color perceived. That's not entirely true. A demonstration of the principle of t conversion (Helson, 1939?) contains a powerful counter example. It's easily demonstrated by a cigarette smoker in an old line Italian restaurant (where Helson first noticed the effect). You'll need a lighted candle in a deep red glass vase. A darkened room and a lighted cigarette with a burning coal held close to the base of the vase. The normally red coal will appear a vivid bright glowing green. Not sort of green but vividly green. Clearly why the optical society of America defines light as radiant energy visual evaluated. Without an eye there is no color or light. As one color scientist put it as the title of a book, "The Rays are Not Coloured." I'm looking forward with pleasure to seeing what you do with this phenomenon. Yes, I am a retired perceptual experimental psychologist who was one of Helson's students.

Light is reflected in this realm.  The eyes see only reflected light.  Color is reflected light.  Depth perception is reflected light.  So what your eyes visualize depends upon your angle of perception.  This is why eye witnesses of an event, standing next to each other usually describe it differently from each other.  To know something is a true illusion, everyone witnessing it, standing next to each other,  will see it the same way,  Those on the perimeter, away from the direct reflection of light, will see it differently, will recognize the illusion as an illusion. one way to see it rotating is you kind of have to turn off your brain and split your focus to all 4 sides of the window, you have to perceive it as it is not as your brain interprets. it is similar to seeing through water looking for fish, unless you have someone point a fish out to you in the water they can be hard to see, basically unless you perceive the scene as what it is most fish will look like undefined shadows, and collections of pebbles, but if you turn off your brain for a second, and stare at the water you will start to notice movements that are not like water, outlines that are too regular and defined, and you will be able to see the fish, not as a shadow, but the details of them. Rainbow trout are really hard to spot, even though they have a very defined pink band, but if you do these things they will stand out at you, almost as much as a neon pink fish would.

with your windows you can take advantage of the fact that it is a 3d object, one side will always lead the other, it doesn't matter how flat you get it, this will always remain true, to me it feels innate to know something is off with the picture, and that cues me to look at the world not as i think it to be but as it is, to actually handle the interpreting and labeling of everything in the scene rather than pass it on to what ever part of the brain will do its best attempt. There is likely a reason people dont tend to do this often and that is because it is tiring, instead of dismissing information that you probably dont need you are basically saying every bit of info is important there is always that one line in some shows or stories of "if the human brain didnt filter things out it would short circuit" but that is a misconception. it is merely tiring, im no expert on history, but im pretty certain when man was hunter gatherer this is how they stayed alive, it is how people were able to spot predators as well as pray, to hunt, and track. It is just that it isnt needed as much anymore and so people don't learn to turn it on, but do hunting, fishing, bird watching, hell probably even photography and you will learn how to do this.

As you briefly mention in your video, the main criteria for this illusion to work is the distance from which the rotating window is observed. The closer you get to the rotating window, the more likely you are to notice that the small height end of the window gets bigger when closer to you. If you're close enough, the tallest end of the window will appear less tall than the short end while the tall end is in the back, thus completely breaking the illusion.

Filming this illusion from a great distance, with heavy zoom, is the very best way to make it nearly impossible to break the illusion, regardless of how many eyes you use to watch it, or how familiar with right angles you are.

When we look with one eye, we see in the 2D dimension, then we see the illusion because we cannot see the depth of space. The 2D dimension is more imperfect in nature than the 3D dimension. When we look with both eyes, we see in 3D (2.5D) dimension, then we can see the depth and the illusion does not exist. That goes for all illusions. Illusions in 3D are very rare! When we look at the screen, the screen is always in 2D no matter what we look with both eyes!

I see perfect oscillation on the smaller ones, but on your big one you fit through things get weird...er.

With 9'oclock being the left, 3 the right, 12 far away and 6 closest to the camera, it looks like the small end starts at 9 o'clock, spins clockwise to 12, then to 3, and so on until 6 o'clock. In this instant we are looking at the thin side and the window in unseen. In the next instant the small end sees to be moving from 12 o'clock counter-clockwise to 9 o'clock and then instantly switches directions and repeating as above.

It's really your legs that give me the most WTF. With the small end at 6 o'clock your legs are at 3 o'clock (because you're hanging out perpendicular), moving clockwise to 6 o'clock while the window appears to be moving counter-clockwise away from them. Thus they're going from moving with the large end behind them to away from the large end in front of them in the same instant the window seems to flip from the large end being behind moving clockwise to in front moving counter-clockwise.

Oh man this was very interesting. This kinda made me think about this thing I've been thinking about for the last year. I
can never know if I truly understand something. Or maybe I can never know if I know. Like no matter what I think and what I'm certain about, there is a plausible reality that could completely flip it on its head, and that could be real. Don't know. And this never really reaches a point of "complete" understanding even in the tiniest of things, if there is such a thing.
And this while it may be true that I can never know if I truly know, if I am actually right, and if it's actually possible to be completely in the know. What's interesting about this is it feels like something in my intuition, like in all humans and animals this must exist right? The room for error, the space we give because we know we may be wrong. It's quite interesting that the ego tries to fill that in right? But it's something that's inherently unfillable. Like we want to feel like we are in control and we know what's what, but it's like a property of reality.
That the same observation might actually have been created or formed from infinite different origins and states.
Does that mean we cannot learn, no. But it does mean that I should be ready for everything I ever knew to be wrong or false or misinformed, and be ready to accept that, that I do not know, and that I can not know if I do know. if I want to continue learning beyond that point, I have to accept it.

It's seems like a very confusing paradox all this, and I have to understand it better.

I have an interesting anecdote to add for you.  I put this in my Watch Later list and waited for my friend to come over today.  Together, we watched it.  I see exactly what you are seeing.  She doesn't, at all.  Not one part of this whole illusion fools her.  I'll be honest, we just kept going over and over and over the first 5 minutes or so but continually, we saw two completely different things.  Why?  She is schizophrenic.  Optical illusions like this often don't work for people with schizophrenia.  Now I have my own mental garbage going on but I am not schizophrenic.  Even though I have been in and out of the world of mental health since I was 6 or 7 years old, I had no idea that using optical illusions such as this is a diagnostic tool used to diagnose (or rule out) schizophrenia, even if said patient is unable to speak (if they cannot speak, most of the time if the patient cannot see the illusion, it won't get their attention at all, or if they can see it, they won't be able to look away or sometimes they will have an abnormal reaction to it because they can't process it.)

VPN doesnt stop the ISP from seeing what sites u visit. it only masks ur IP addy. but they dont use the IP addy to track u they use the MAC addy which gets transfered to the IP addy the VPN gives u. When u use a VPN it alerts the spyware at the ISP server that ur doing something thats blocked so it triggers the tracing software.

IP addy can be shared amoung several households but the mac addy is unique to every device.
Plus the VPN doesnt kick in till after u have gone through the ISP and the VPN stops once the site ur visiting goes back to the ISP before getting back to ur device.

if u go into settings and find ur IP addy u will also see MAC addy or device ID. thats what they use to track u and it cant be changed or masked in any way.

I just started the video, and I think I understand. The window you're leaning through is only a couple of millimetres in width, maybe less. You have painted the edge of the windows and the wall on the side facing the camera at the start grey. Then, on the other side, you have mirrored the image so it looks the exact same when it passes the camera, so it looks like it stopped because of how the camera is positioned in relation to the wall. What is actually happening is you have kept swinging around, using the mirrored grey spots to make it look like the same side of when you stopped, which is causing the illusionary effect because the brain is automatically processing that it has stopped, but because of perspective it seems to be sucked through your body because when it is actually still moving, it seems to have stayed still, as I mentioned before. This stinks because we're seeing it on a 2D screen and our eyes tend to scan back and forth looking for depth. The trick to figure it out is pick a spot on the back of the trapezoid and continue to look at tit. As soon as you move your eyes you lose perspective. He gives it away here:
https://youtu.be/dBap_Lp-0oc?t=192
If you notice all of the sudden the longer side on the right gets hit by a beam of light. This makes you realize the cardboard is almost parallel to the camera. Continue to look at the spot that gets hit by light and you'll see the rotation.
Don't look at the center of the object, look at the part with the most angular velocity, the edge.

The difference between 2D visual cues for distance and stereoscopic visual cues is interesting. That study with the 80 children is a good example. The further away you are from an object, the smaller the parallax in the images received by each of your eyes, and the more you have to rely on 2D visual cues. The 'Carpentered Environment' seems like it's training us to rely more on 2D visual cues even in situations where parallax may be large enough to go with stereoscopic (3D) cues.

"...so we should approach the world and our conclusions about it with a little more humility and a little less certainty." No, no, no! Don't make such a blanket statement. Some things are clearly wrong, and should be identified as being wrong. Your statement is much too close to saying that reality is subjective. It is not. There is a discernable reality/truth behind everything. Just because you don't have all the tools you need to definitively discern the truth, don't know what that truth is, or have a different impression of what the truth is relative to someone else, does not mean truth doesn't exist. Science RELIES on this, and the scientific method is what allows us to figure out what is true and what isn't (or what is most likely to be true and what is most likely to not be true at any given time). We should actually be injecting more scientific thinking into how we approach the world and our conclusions about it, rather than doing so "with more humility and less certainty."  These are necessary but not sufficient--they are PART OF the scientific process, but they do not MAKE UP  the scientific process. When people have views of the world and come to conclusions about the world which are not testable or relatable to anything widely considered "real world," then other views and conclusions which DO lend themselves to testing and real world comparison MUST take precedence.

Rather than saying "the average weight of Fe is 55.85", I'd rather see more information, specifically: "Fe[28]=5.8%, Fe[30]=91.8%, Fe[31]=2.1%, Fe[32]=0.3%" where the number in brackets represents the number of neutrons in each isotope (and the percentages represents the distribution of the isotopes, preferably by numeric count rather than by weight.) One minor correction to your depth perception example. Lighting- which is generally assumed to come from above rather than below (as in most familiar environments)- is another important cue in addition to parallax motion. Therefore most people would identify the figure with shading at the bottom as protruding toward the camera and the one with shading at the top as an impression, even before they started to move.

The rubix cube and ruler got me lol. Everything else not so much due to either seeing the sides of the paper being a bit separated or lighting.

That being said, you talked about the illusion being due to one side being larger than the other but for me its the painted shadow. When the large end passes by, it makes sense but once it swings away the shadow would normally be hidden if its a 3d object but because it doesn't I see the oscillating pattern.
Lighting and the sides of the paper breaks this illusion due to giving us more things for our eyes to track allowing us to see what's really happening. I believe that Adelbert Ames is correct about people being use to rectangles see the illusion stronger than people who don't but I personally believe its the painted shadows that really sell the illusion. Everyone since the beginning of time uses light to see and with light we see shadows. Shadows are one of the main ways we determine depth so removing it or altering it can mess with our sense of depth drastically for everyone. The lack of detail helps prevent our eyes from picking up any other detail so that we can only determine what's going on based off our knowledge of what should happen.
There is one thing I'm interested to know though, what if there was a dot on one side? Would we still see it as oscillating with the dot appearing and disappearing or would it break the illusion entirely?

@Veritasium...
The interpretation (@6:20) that the fact that more "participants see the oscillating motion" when the "window" is farther back is not something I find surprising. Much less contradicting "Ames's theory". It can very simply be down to the fact that what the participants are observing is now GEOMETRICALLY MUCH closer to that of a "truly oscillating motion" ((Maybe even indistinguishable from one depending on the model and other circumstances. Especially so when viewed with only one eye.)) And so if You "task" Your participants to perceive the oscillating motion... many more will... Regardless of whether they have been raised in "carpentered environments" or not...
So although interesting, and for sure a very good demonstration to for clearly showing how easily we can be fooled by "most trusted sense" regarding "what is really happening"...
I can not help but feeling as if You to a certain extent is "misusing" the fact that we can be "fooled" by this illusion and "downplaying" the OBJECTIVE FACT that still remains , that the "Ames window" IS rotating and NOT oscillating, in Your continued "reasoning" regarding things being "subjective".
And (in my opinion) the FACT that most of us are susceptible to this illusion, when USING ONLY our own senses does NOT really say anything to "profound" about "Science". Or it's the ability to investigate and describe the world around us, more than just "don't trust Your own senses "to far", and NEVER as the only input".
Now don't misunderstand me, I'm all for making people more open to the possibility that their personal interpretation might not be "universally correct" or at least be highly influenced by their specific biases and context. And I of course also appreciate and want "intellectual humility".
I'm less enthusiastic for promoting the general sense"(pun intended) that "science doesn't wprl" pr "can't really tell the difference", just because there are "different perspectives".
I would rather just emphasise that for a scientific modell /statement to be true and correct. it should be "made" AND understood within a comprehensive and clearly defined context.
Best regards.

I've always assumed that this kind of illusion only works when presented on a screen. Since when we're watching video, we're having to convert the 2d image we see on the screen, back to the 3d object being viewed by the camera. It's like if you have a photo of a cat and print it out. We will see it as a picture of a cat. Even though we'll identify quite clearly as a cat we'll still know it's only a flat picture of a cat. So we can get all the clues of depth and colour from the picture to work out what's being represented in the picture, yet still have no illusion that it's a real 3 dimensional cat.

So now when we watch your ames window illusion online, we're watching a 2 dimensional screen and having to take those clues to invent a virtual 3 dimensional reality that the 2d screen represents. We're still aware that the display is 2 dimensional but it has images that represent a 3 dimensional reality and it's THIS virtual 3 dimensional reality that is so easy to manipulate.

But you're saying this illusion works in the real world? So showing someone that rotating piece of flat card will produce the illusion? I'm not sure I believe that.

The vertical edges of the card don't seem to be changing angular size as they either approach or recede from the viewer. This removes the perception of distance. So when the the short side swings towards us, it doesn't seem to get larger, but remains the same size. This gives us the notion that it didn't in fact get closer to us. Note that the illusion relies on viewing it from a distance.

One aspect that wasn't mentioned was the thickness, or the lack of, of the window. Shading infers a depth, or thickness, to the window. As it rotates one would expect to see the window from "on edge" and get a sense of how thick the window frame is. By beveling of the edges and proper shading, the brain is never given a chance to see the "edge" of the window.  So the natural assumption would be that the window stopped just before showing the edge and then oscillated back, to just before showing the opposite edge, and then back and forth.
