Quite surprisingly the metaphor suggested at the end of the video is surprisingly well fitting for once. To be unable force your mind to perceive such a simple optical illusion correctly is a strong case against our ability to intuitively find the optimal decisions. The proposal for letting go of the certainty - realizing and accepting that one's intuition might sometimes be misleading - would do good for most of us (yours truly included of course). I don't know if there's a name for the phenomenon but I've been noticing that the less people know about something the more certain and absolute they are about their opinions on it (and vice versa). Take climate change, nuclear energy and nowadays virology for example - these are some of the hardest concepts to grasp in our modern world, yet almost anyone seems to not only have an opinions but very strong one about each. This of course is not anything spectacular - as you gather knowledge of pretty much anything, you also become aware of the complexity it concerns and are forced to abandon any simple black and white perspectives regarding it. Unfortunately, people who don't have this experience about anything might be hard convince to see how it works and this could be a part of the problem why populism is such an effective strategy. In my opinion this is a serious matter in today's world where any message can be relayed to a huge audience via the internet and developing strategies to fight it should be in the top priority list of mankind. I'd go as far as saying it is even more important than, say, climate change since it is a tool (and possibly often the reason too) for populism that often aims to neglect the problems (like climate change) we should be be taking very seriously.

The brain seems to be doing the same thing as computer games do - they often don't calculate the entire picture, but cheat. Calculate just a small amount and try to make an assumption. This way you can save a massive amount of computations at the expense of rare side effects. In the case of the brain - the side effects may be these illusions.

If the brain didn't assume anything (that should be a rectangle), but instead calculated every single pixel properly - it probably wouldn't happen.

I just want to note that, don't forget that this is a trait of viewing the world through, essentially, a pinhole. Consider the fact that, what we think we see in front of us is a flat image, so you would think our field of vision can be represented by a rectangular cube in front of us. But really, our field of vision is 2 cones intersecting. As such, in order for our brains to process the image as something we can deal with, we "squeeze" (not really, but the best way I can explain it) the conic images into a rectangular format, the wider side of the cone has to "squeeze" into smaller space of the rectangle. And as such, has to be "squeezed smaller" in our vision. And this "squeezing", gives up vanishing points with the horizon line and gravity(giving us up and down via seeing animals and trees, etc. ), naturally gives us rectangular angles and trapezoidal angles. (and perspective). Please pardon the crude explanation. I'm an artist, not a neurologist. This is something that most artists learn (or should have learned).

I do have to note that, yes, the lighting has to be "the same" (basically, enough light to bleach out the details that would signify one side from the other) on both sides of the window. But also if the rotational axis had been closer to the smaller end (or maybe even directly in the middle) of the window, that probably break the illusion. Because that would give enough of a difference in the size of the larger side of the window when it's up close as oppose to when it's further for our eyes/brain to notice.

I believe this phenomenon also can be applied to other items besides pictures. I used to be a financial analyst at a hospital. My duties required me to generate one large report which contained multiple subsets of the same data creating a report that contained Accounts Receivable financial billing, reimbursement and contractual write offs or adjustments of medical bills that were further broken down by individual specialist and primary care doctors. The data was repotted by financial groups Medicare, Medicaid, Managed Healthcare Insurance, Blue Cross/Blue Shield and others. The report showed also showed productivity reports created by what CPT was reported on the submitted bill to the insurance carrier(s). Because it CPT is grouped into a certain subset. For example a 99211 is an for an office or outpatient evaluation and management code for an established patient . Office/outpatient evaluation and management visits are coded in a group from 99211 through 99215. The difference between each number is the amount of time spent with the patient and number of systems examined. Someone going in to have blood pressure checked might be scored as 99211- while if that same patient had instead had bp, an echocardiogram, and discussion of 3 or more illnesses like diabetes, copd, and also has pneumonia might be coded as a 99215. There are several other groups of evaluation and management groups besides this example. If a doctor is seeing patients on a regular schedule, this information can be plotted out in a graph. If the doctor is properly coding his encounters with his patients properly the productivity report should generate a bell curve graph.

This is an enormous report created for 35 different offices and over 300 physicians, physician assistants and nurses. These reports need to generated every month and when providers generate submit this information, they expect all information to be generated fast, friendly to read and above all information correct . I created a program that would run algorithms to cross check the finished reports. The source data when added to previous month and and fiscal year to date information. If a cross check failed there was conditional rules that if cross checks failed their information on the page turned. The report red. If all checks balanced correctly, the report would not have any.red conditionals and just app as a normal report. Then I got a co-worker to help me with the checks. Let me give you further information. I am dyslexic and prior to working with the person assigned to my group. She looked a my proofing algorithms and said they made no sense to her. She then showed me her algorithms she used to proof the same reports. Just a further bit of information- I am dyslexic and my proofs kept my reports error for the last 10 years. But when my coworker reviewed that data and proof by a method that was completely opposite of what I came.up with. I investigated her proof. Hers worked the same way as mine but used a different perspective. I have the ability to see the data in my head and can visualize the hierarchy and relationships to all the reports in a 3 dimensional relationship. I could see it clearly and could visualize all connections. My partner lacked that ability and her brain saw other patterns my mind missed and her method created a double check on that same data. We built both types of verification checks into the whole system of reports. This only strengthened our abilities to generate a flawless report accurate to the penny and proceedure. We both could now see that we saw the data in exact opposite views and we turned that process to our advantage. We each saw the same information but in opposite ways, we them turned it into our greatest strength.

What wasn't talked about and is key to this illusion is true perspective vs drawn or virtual perspective.

When you look at something in the real world, the father away it or a portion of the object is, the smaller it is. The closer, the bigger.

When viewing something at a great distance, using camera at a great distance or using a special lense and software the amount of real perspective can be reduced so things don't appear to get smaller the farther away they are.

When you physically draw something or make an object you can add virtual perspective to create the appearance of distance. Items or portions of objects you want to appear father away would be deliberated drawn/made smaller then items or portions of objects you want to appear closer.

What is being done here is the object has been created with a large amount of virtual perspective and if you look closely you can see the real world perspective has been deliberately minimized. Look at the size of the ruler as it spins. The closer end should become larger than the farther end but it doesn't so the real perspective is minimal.

Another thing to keep in mind is in the real world we also have the ability to estimate distance by a combination of parallax and focus as well. (On a 2D screen we only have perspective).

Parallax is caused by viewing the same real world scene from two separate but close locations (two eyes) at the same time. Our brains considers the fact that closer objects will move slightly with respect to farther objects and use this to help estimate distance. Focus is the fact that your eyes (or a camera) will need to use a different focal length to get a clear image for different distances and again your brain uses this to help estimate distance.

With only perspective available when viewing a 2d screen (computer screen, tv or phone) and having the real perspective minimized using one of the methods (such as viewing from a distance), if the image contains large amounts of virtual perspective it is expected that our brains conclude the window is rotating back and forth instead of around continuously.

One thing worth thinking about if you've got this far is 3D TVs and 3D movies and why they don't feel realistic (and sometimes result in headaches or feeling ill). 3D TV/movies are generated using both virtual perspective (smaller object size when farther away) and parallax (different views for each eye). The parallax is created by using 2 lenses separated by a similar distance to eye separation and then using some method to replay those separated lense captures back to your individual eyes (polarization, color, frame blocking, etc). 3D TVs/movies are not able to simulate true distance so your eyes only need to focus on the single distance of the screen. The problem is that your brain expects you to need a different focus for distant vs close objects when viewing in 3d. To many people this is a major issue and kills the enjoyment added by current 3D tech. There are some more advanced 3D technologies that combine the combination of projection, parallax, and focus but unfortunately they are both extremely expensive and currently suffer from poor image quality.

For now our TVs, computers and phones will have to make do with just using perspective to indicate distance, which means if the perspective is deliberately modified we will be unable to properly judge distance...

Things like this are just one reason I don't believe any of the ghost/demon/big foot/etc photos and videos, so many of them are pareidolia or an optical illusion. Too many people insist that their senses are 100% reliable so it can't possibly be that they misunderstood something or misheard a sound or simply never paid attention to something until someone pointed it out (Mandela effect, I mean you!). Our senses are not that trustworthy, our brains literally make things up if we can't immediately make sense of something, and that's what makes science a vital method of discerning reality, by having those perceptions challenged, criticized,, dissected, and tossed if they don't hold up. Did I see a "shadow person" standing by my bed when I was two years old? Maybe, I guess. Did I misinterpret something I saw, or thought I saw, or I was half asleep and dreaming but convinced myself I was awake? That is the most reasonable conclusion. Was it still a scary, creepy experience? Of course it was! But that doesn't make it *real*.

This is why the flat earth debate is so infuriating, too. Your eyes and ears do not give you a 100% accurate view of reality, you need to get over the fact that you could be wrong and look at the evidence that's been collected, challenged, and triumphed by people way the hell smarter than you are. I don't see the sun moving across the sky, I see the earth rotating.

The sense of motion can and often does play into the same illusion: You're sitting on a train pulling into a station and slowing to a stop, but the train next to you is accelerating away from stopping. If you're caught unawares looking at the adjacent train, your senses swear that you are accelerating backwards, not decelerating forwards. It often induces motion sickness and/or vertigo. Stare at the Ames Window, and the same mental gyrations are at work.

I believe that this is also related to the phenomenon of car tyres seemingly changing spin direction when they get fast enough. OUr brains interpolate a LOT of what we visually perceive, so if something is shaped just the right way to fit in those gaps the brain is used to fill itself, it can work directly against "experiences"...
In the case of the tires our visual cortex isn't perceiving continuously but takes kind of snapshots, so if the new state of the next image we "see" is closer to what the brain expects a wheel rolling backwards should look we perceive the wheel as spinning against its direction of travel.

This fake window object seems to fall into the same kind of "shoulda kinda" perceptions.

Tres ccool. seel the oscillating illusion .... but for the window almost immediately spotted and anomaly that triggerred a ... something not right ... by the apparent bowing of the top and bottom edges. It appears to go from in to out (rather bowing bottom to top) at the apparent "stop". As with most illusions by the end of the vid I would (considerable concentration effort)
see the "reality" of rotation. (at this point I can look at the skater silohuette and "choose" to see it rotating in either direction). In 3d in motion it's impossible for a visual "illusion" to be perfect. .... a static illusion in 3d can be perfect (at least from far enough away) but a moving one gives subtle clues ... like the seeming "bowing" of the window top and bottom edges (an artifact of 2d interpretation of a 3d image ... but "real" in the sense that it is "real" as captured by the camera. Of course in a digitalized image the clues could ... by a skilled team of visual artists, or more likely a competent AI be removed so that in the digitalized 2d raster projection over time there are no remaining clues of the falsity. And as stated in the video, for a static image (at sufficient range where our two eyes can no longer distingush) it is impossible to know the 3d reality of a complex percept.

What you are talking about in this video is all about "perspective experiences" of our brain. Our brain has a regulated definition about perspective, based on visual experiences. And misunderstanding of our brain is normally acceptable for us, when we use the perspective rules in other way.
But there is an important point that you didn't talk about it: The misunderstanding happens only when we watch the subject through just ONE point (like by one eye, or through a camera or in the video) and also in a fixed position (not moving our head or place). If the subject be seen by both eyes, the trick will be recognizable and misunderstanding will not happen. Therefore the visual test which has been performed on babies, is completely invalid. Because watching the subject with both eyes, reveals the truth to any viewer, whether child or adult.

the book Visual Intelligence by Hoffman fully explains how our brains do not "perceive" at all, but rather construct -- from scratch -- whatever we are looking at, using everything we've ever associated with similar images in the past. this can mean sounds, smells, ... anything. These are all just one huge network of tons of little neural firings that are reactivated on the spot to actively -- not passively -- recreate our world. In fact, if you ask where in the brain the memory for a square is, for example, it's all over the place. remembering equals constructing, recognizing equals creating, memorization is perception

I made 2D games in the 2000's and would make 2D objects look like they were spinning by simply squishing them then reversing the squish. To add thickness so it's not paper-thin, you just don't have the image squish to so few pixels wide. If you have any details on the sprite that aren't symmetric then you need to "unsquish" a mirrored image instead of the same image at the second half of the animation sequence.

A fantastic illusion morphed into a great morale about how we perceive life.  I learned a long time ago that I can be fooled into thinking I have enough information if I just look at one side of a story, like just listening to the prosecution in a court case.  When I was a child, I remember thinking, "I've heard enough, the other side can save their breath." Then I heard the other side, and was shocked. Humility followed and I realized that in order to understand life, we need as much data as we can get to come to a conclusion about a thing. Thanks, Veritasium, for reminding me of this. I think knowing our biases especially today in American is really important as we typically look for things that support them rather than try to challenge them, put them to the test, so to speak. Truth is important enough to keep our judgements in abeyance long enough to look at them from different angles before we settle on what we believe is real.

Basically what his explanation means is that human perception uses lighting and shading to depict the movement of an object. Since the illusion has drawn on shading, it appears to oscillate when rotating because the brain is confused as to what direction the illusion is rotating when the bigger side is behind (or going behind) the smaller side. So it's just drawn on shading confusing the eyes and brain.

I couldn't make the window stop oscillating until after you had made the full size and climbed into it. At first, it still oscillated, but I managed to see it stop oscillating and start rotating; if I stopped concentrating on the rotation, it went back to oscillating. The change in illusion, to me, is like fighting a dominant eye while sighting down a shotgun barrel with both eyes open. If the dominant eye is the one aligned with the barrel, all you see is the top of the barrel getting smaller as it approaches the muzzle. If you can concentrate on the weak eye's view, you suddenly see the barrel from a slight angle from one side. Stop concentrating, and the dominant eye view returns.

Ok so I think I figured it out for myself. If I start to think of how it interacts in 3d and project that on the image in my head I can break the illusion. But if I stop thinking about that 3d interaction I can bring it back.

It's how we've gotten to a place like this where basically "my gender is whatever I say it is" or "to me, America started in 1619" or "my truth is just as valid as yours" even though one method of knowing facts gets you to the moon and cures disease or gives you a deeper understanding of reality and the others are just a flawed episteme that tries to legitimize itself to suit an agenda.

The disingenuous undertone to this whole video, the timing and the message it tries to convince the viewers of reeks of sjw propaganda disguised as an educational video. This isn't the first time Vertasium has exploited the current societal discussion to further a particular side of the argument either.

Then there's the flaws with the message in the video itself. He uses an example of a known phenomenon to try to make the case that nothing is certain. Yet we are pretty certain of the phenomenon taking place. We recognize the flaws within our brain and compensate for that in other ways (by looking at the object from different perspectives) to obtain the truth behind what is really happening. Our brains are not carefully fixed cameras viewing an object at one angle all the time, thus there's a false equivalence happening here. Our brains can view things from different reference frames which is how we know the object is spinning, even though we also know that from certain angles it looks differently than others. So the idea that just because certain reference frames can be exploited in special, specific conditions means that all reference frames are untrustworthy is a false assumption. Because you mentioned the problem of the isotropy of the speed of light again:
You can maybe not measure the oneway speed of light, but you can still show that it is isotropic. Here are two thought-experiments:

1.) Take 3 star ships (A,B and C), moving parallel to each other in free space in a way, that there are in the same frame of inertia. The distance AB shall be equal to the distance BC and half of the distance AC (B is located in the middle of AC). Each of them has a very precise clock aboard. To synchronize the clocks, B sends a signal to A and C. First let's assume a isotropic speed of light c:
The Signal needs 1 sec to reach the other two space ship. If the clock B showed 00:00:00 when the signal was send, the clocks A and C are showing 00:00:00 when the signal arrives. For an observer in A, the clocks A and B are perfectly synchronized: if the observer in A looks to the clock B, it shows the same time as the clock A. However, the clock C is for the obsever in A about 2 seconds delayed: The signal for 00:00:00 C time arrives 00:00:02 A time. An observer in C would see the very same events as the obsever in A, because of the symmetry of the problem. The observer in B sees both clocks A and C delayed as the time the signal needs to travel from B to A and back (or from B to C and back) is again 2 seconds. Now the ships A and C perform a rotational symmetric maneuver and switch places. The time dilatation dt is, as long the speed of the ships during the maneuver v << c, negliable to the travel-time of the signals dt<<t(xy) with t(xy) ={ t(AB)==t(BA), t(AC)==t(CA), t(BC)==t(CB) }. Even more imporant: the observations of an observer in A are still identical to the observations to an observer in C and the time by wich the clocks A and C are delayed to an observer in B is identical, too. Thus for an observer in A, the clock B is still synchronized (if you neglect the small difference dt) and the clock C is still delayed by 2 seconds (analogue for C) and for the observer in B, still both clocks A and C are delayed by 2 seconds.
Now repeat the same experiment with anisotropic speed of light. In the direction AB, AC and BC the speed of light shall be infinity, in the opposite direction c/2. One of the major aspects of SRT is the lorentz-invariance of space time. Despite having an anisotropic c, the formulas for coordinate system transformation are still the same! So B sends a signal at 00:00:00 B time. It arrives instantaneously in C (now synched to 00:00:00 C time) and arrives 2 seconds later in A (now showing 00:00:00 A time). For the observer in A, the clocks A and B are perfectly synchronized: the signal for 00:00:00 send in 00:00:00 B time arrives in 00:00:00 A time. The clock C however is for an observer in A about 2 seconds delayed: the signal 00:00:00 C time arrives A at 00:00:02 A time. For the observer in C, the clock B is perfectly synchronized, where as the clock A is about 2 seconds delayed. For the observer in B, both clocks A and C are 2 seconds delayed. Until now, everything seems to be identical to the case of the isotropic speed of light. But now A and C perform again the maneuver. As the formulas of the SRT are still valid, the time dilation for two objects moving at a relative speed of v<< c is still negliable! The Lorentz-Factor γ = 1/sqrt(1 - (v/c(ϑ))²) is still close to one (or beeing exactly 1 for c = infinity), despite having only a speed of light c/2 in one direction ϑ. But what does the different observers measure?! The observer in C (now at the former position of A) would see, that the clock B is now 2 seconds delayed and the clock A even 6 seconds!! For the observer B, the clock C is now synchronized, whereas clock C is now 4 seconds delayed. For the observer in A, now both clocks B and C are 2 seconds ahead! Not only are the observers in A and C measuring different things, all observers are measuring notably different time differences between the clocks compared to the situation before the maneuver.

Conclusion: A spacetime with an anisotropic speed of light would be NOT rotational invariant!!

There is also a more practical and realizable way to proof the isotropy of the speed of light:
2.) Take a monochromatic source of light, e.g. a laser. An electron relaxing from an excited state to an lower state emitts a photon with the Energy E=hν equal to the energy-difference of these two states. Frequency and wavelength of an electromagnetic wave (as well as of any other wave) are connected by the simple equation c = λν, where c is the phase velocity. In the case of a photon of an monochromatic light source this is equal to the speed of the photon itself: the speed of light. If c = c(ϑ) is depending on the direction ϑ, the wavelength of the laser would change, depending from which angle you are looking an the light source (remember: ν cannot change, because it is determined by the quantum-mechanical transition of the emitting electron).

You see: perhabs we cannot measure the one-way speed of light directly, but would it be anisotropic it would cause a hell a amount of trouble.

After watching this video, I realized that you might be very interested in Henri Poincaré's analysis of how human physiology caused us to arrive at Euclidean geometry. When you ask, "how do we develop the ability to interpret depth queues in the first place?", I believe you are considering a very similar question to the one Poincare posed. His answer is that our ability to translate our own position (i.e. move) to offset the motion of another object, (i.e. keep its position on our retina the same), is what induces Euclidean geometry. Perhaps that's what is different beteen babies at 5 months and 7 months (the ability to crawl and move)?

To your main point that many interpretations of the same data are possible, you may be aware that Poincaré, among his many other accomplishments, introduced non-Euclidean geometry into Physics, which is why the question of how Euclidean geometry originated probably held great interest to him.

You can find that essay under the title "Space and Geometry" (Chapter 4) in a collection of his philisophical writings titled "The Value of Science" (editor Stephen Jay Gould).

My brain only slightly prefers the standard illusion... but then, I have highly atypical neurology.

It doesn't take much for me to see the 360 degree rotations. I get to choose whether it's clockwise or counterclockwise as long as the card is perfectly flat and the lighting is ideal. I can switch between CW/CCW at will, not just when it is edge-on... but I have to set up the expectation just ahead of time. Once I see continuous rotation it takes a higher conscious effort to go back to oscillation, as oscillation makes less sense once rotation has been seen.

But as soon as you interfere with the illusion (by adding ruler or Rubiks cube) or if there's even a barely noticeable camber to the card or a slight left-right light or tone imbalance - then I find it almost impossible to maintain the oscillation and it's harder to see reversed rotation... so, it breaks the illusion almost entirely, and my brain develops a very strong, almost unbreakable, preference for the proper rotation.

I definitely cannot see a Rubik cube or ping-pong ball "orbit" an oscillating window - the visual clues are all wrong for that - so my brain refuses.

However, I am aware that my brain is physically and neurologically very atypical. I am autistic, with full-field visual thinking and synesthesia ... and my brain performs a lot of processing on a rather enlarged/overdeveloped optical pathway, which 'lights up' with activity when I try to solve spatial or geometric problems or imagine situations.

I often have two complete and non-overlapping visual fields at the same time - one actual and one imaginary... although, at times, concepts from each can mutually interfere. As a child I often had two rich visual/auditory worlds occurring at the same time - I imagine it's much like schizophrenia must be, but with considerably more conscious control over the content.

My brain has been studied quite a lot at the local teaching/research hospital - so I've been able to get a lot of insight into my peculiar neurology.

Most moving optical illusions simply don't work at all on me - even if I 'will them' to - so this one must be particularly strong.

The key take away here is that this best-interpretation-of-ambiguous-data-based-on-past-experience-both-personal-and-evolutionary principle applies not just to optical phenomena, but how we perceived other aspects of the world.  For example, we tend to misinterpret natural phenomena in terms of social phenomena (e.g. volcanoes caused by gods) because our brains are hyper-tuned to function in a highly social environment.  With some effort, you can retrain yourself to see the card as spinning rather than oscillating, but it takes effort and trust in our analytical understanding into how the world truly works (science).  The same applies to other natural phenomena in our world (a volcano is the result of natural principles in play, not the product of an agent with a social agenda).  Our unconscious bias towards certain people also falls into this category. I can't overstate how much better our world would be if more people understood this inherent deficiency in perception and relied less heavily on intuition and superficial interpretation.

It's not just the shape of the window, but painting false edges and shaded surfaces to give it a 3-D appearance is a very strong influence. It would have been interesting to compare the painted window to one with the same shape that doesn't have the false surfaces painted on it.

I think it's also important whether we're looking at it on a flat surface, like on a video screen, or seeing it in the real world. The comparison of results for one eye vs two eyes is important when seeing the object in the real world, since both eyes would be able to get slight clues as to the true perspective, while viewing on a video screen would not.

Edit: And I think it's important to mention that the vertical position of one's eyes is critical to the success of the illusion. The effect will be less dramatic the more your eyes are above or below the plane of rotation. I can't help but think that the tests which were done probably didn't take this into account. A good test of age or cultural influence should be done using video -- a cleaner test tube, so to speak.

Now that I know what to look for, I could actually see the rotation of the circle. Once I could see that, I went back and tried again with the window, cube, and ruler. I can actually follow the rotation now. A clue... With the window, watch the dark rectangle at the very edge. When it starts to get to the point where it turns, remind yourself that it is now going BEHIIND the card. And when it comes clear again, remind yourself it is the same bar, other side, now coming clear on the opposite side. Once you have trained yourself to remember the distinct sides, it almost becomes simple. Took me about ten seconds. You could make it easier to see this, if you put a different color dot in the center of the dark bar, but only on one side. I would assume that if you trained yourself with the one with a dot, then you could go back to the dotless example, and still be able to see the true spin.

Projection mapping at its finest. This is a side effect of perceiving a 3D world with 2D sensors (hence why this is so hard on video. fundamentally, our image/light data is only a plan (only 2 dimension plus color, our brain infer 3D in it with some quarks). Every expectations is based on an assumption wich can be deceived ... (like any social conscruct, any sense, any idea, anything ...). Extrapolation isn't (always) "real" but often true (and a shortcut our brain like).

I can personally attest to the notion that depth perception is developed in early childhood. I was effectively blind until I got eye surgery at 18 months. If anyone picked me up, I would cry until I heard their voice since I couldn't identify them by sight. I also never walked prior to the surgery, but within hours of removing the bandages covering my eyes, I was walking.

To this day I don't have stereoscopic depth perception. I can see through both eyes, but they're slightly misaligned, which probably doesn't help. If I'm talking to someone from too far away, they'll sometimes think I'm talking to someone behind them since one of my eyes isn't looking directly at them. Because of the misalignment, there's no overlap of the two images for the brain to determine depth information.

You totally missed what makes us see occiliation: It's not the X and Y dimensions of the window (although they contribute too), but it's the blue Z planes inside the window quarters and on the outside edge that are painted as if shown from one specific direction.  Their shrinking can be attributed to one specific direction of spinning in reality, so our brain can only be led to see that. And since the image is mirrored on both sides of the board -  it spins in the opposite directions depending on what side we see, thus we see an occilation between the two sides.

I love that point at the end about questioning what data is really telling us and if we've really narrowed down the truth to just one answer! The certainty we often have in our lives is more about pre-conceptions than actually ruling out all alternative hypotheses. To take the Copernican example, tons of very intelligent scientists at the time thought heliocentrism was debunked because the math didn't work as well as geocentric epicycles, but the real thing debunked was only heliocentrism with perfectly circular orbits. But also until our measurements got better there was no real way to tell if it was the heliocentrism that was the problem or the circular orbits that was. This is why it's good to even consider ideas that may as a whole be falsified, because maybe there are salvageable portions of an idea that do point to important truths. And of course sometimes there won't be. But if this whole gaining knowledge thing was easy we'd already be done with it!

The rubiks cube in this video is fake and unsolvable (I believe it is actually just a cube with some coloured paper on it)
1. The centers are wrong (or they just used a wierd colour scheme which literally nobody uses).
2. There is an edge piece which is comprised of 2 green stickers which is impossible.
3. There are two white-orange edge pieces which is also Impossible.
4. At least 3 of the corner pieces have 2 red stickers on, which is impossible because no piece can have the same colour more than once.
5. One of the corner pieces is completely white, which (as I have already explained) is impossible.
6. There are 2 green centers which is impossible as there are 6 different colours meaning that even if the colour scheme is really weird, it is still impossible for there to be two center which are the same.

I think I have made my point clear.
When simulating a rubik's cube, at least try basing it off an actual scrambled rubiks cube rather than just picking random colours. I mean seriously, you can get top end rubiks cubes for like £10 and if you just want one for show, you can get them for like £3-5.

13:46 - Those are not "different external realities". The Earth rotating or the Sun (and the whole universe) revolving around it are equivalent, it's just a matter of what you pick as your reference point. There is no "or"; there is no "debate".

To quote Mr. A. Einstein: "[the debate is] quite meaningless. Either CS [coordinate system] could be used with equal justification. The two sentences, 'the Sun is at rest and the Earth moves,' or 'the Sun moves and the Earth is at rest,' would simply mean two different conventions concerning two different CS."

That was also one of Stephen Hawkings' pet peeves (people saying "the Earth goes around the Sun, not the other way around"). Teachers who tell children that early on make it much harder for them to understand relativity later. Physics works no matter which coordinate system you pick (some are just more practical for some calculations).

Why does it work in 3d for some? Because some people didn't develop a 3d stereoscopic interpretation of the world they see. They have two eyes, but somehow don't use that extra information to see 3d. Hence 2d projection tricks work on them in 3d. (they use assumed sizes, shading etc to estimate depth instead)

If the observed data is consistent with multiple hypotheses then that is not a good test to differentiate between the hypotheses. In fact that is precisely why it is impossible to verify a hypothesis, rather than falsifying it: because observations always under-determine theory. You can check whether a theory is compatible with the observations or not, and if it's not you can rule it out, but if it is, that tells you nothing, because it's always also compatible with something else too.

First off, the window, as we know it, is a certain shape no matter how we see it or view it, and we can be certain of this. Now, to approach life with a little less certainty does not sound like a proper thing to say. It is rather that one should not be certain until one has all the facts. Now, there is a question as to when all of the facts have been gathered, but this is a separate question. If, for this comment, we assume that all facts have been gathered, or all necessary facts have been gathered, on a particular subject, then we can arrive to certainty on that subject. Humility and humbleness are not the correct character traits that should be advocated for, as they coverup the negative that is apparent inside a certain type of view. That view is false confidence. When one avoids, discards, disregards, dismisses, skips, is impatient, is lazy, is unethical, is irrational, and then proceeds to rest upon an immat
ure set of ideas, then one will arrive to false confidence. One can arrive to an immature set of ideas and not settle upon that set as the end, and so will not proceed as if they do have a complete set of ideas, but will proceed with certainty that one has certain ideas that can be confidently continued with and other ideas that need further proof. Confidence and certainty of one's lack of knowledge of something is not uncertainty, but is being objective and rational about one's approach to knowledge, the world, and nature.

Thanks for an interesting video!
I found that the larger Ames window with you in it didn't work at all for me. I was clearly seeing it rotating, even at the start of the video, before learning what illusion to look out for. Can't really put my finger on what was clueing me in about rotation, and the illusion worked perfectly on the following smaller pieces.
Also, as one of my eyes is nearly blind, I lack all the binocular depth and movement clues, so monocular ones are better developed. Because of that, I often find myself failing to see some illusions other people say are very convincing, especially of the "close one eye to see the illusion" variety. On the other hand, I fall for some illusions that everyone else sees through (and sometimes see an illusion where none was intended at all). I never studied it much, but one general observation I have is this: it feels that monocular clues are much weaker at a distance, because compared to binocular people, I have no problem when dealing with things up close, but struggle even with basic distance/speed/shape estimations for distant objects. On the other hand, when a person with a binocular vision closes one eye, their perception becomes noticeably worse than mine.
I wonder if this is what happened in the South Africa study you mentioned: children had to rely only on monocular clues, which is something they weren't used to, and the increased distance made it only harder to perceive through the illusion.
And it also makes me wonder: the human brain is very plastic, and there are a lot of different visual clues it learn can use. If we had, say, a person that lived from birth locked in a bunker, surrounded by various illusions, would they be fooled by those illusions, or would they adapt? And when they would finally get out, would they be greatly confused by things we take for granted? How much of the vision is hardwired, and how much is learned?

I think this really underscores how little of our visual processing system is under volitional control. Even when you know the illusion is there, you can't command your brain to un-see it. It has to be that way, of course, because the essential problem in vision is how to map the 2D projection on our retinas into a 3D model (Stephen Pinker calls this 2 1/2 D). This is massively underdetermined, as the video says, so we have to have developed heuristics. And those heuristics need to be fast, pretty good, and not subject to second-guessing, because if you spend too much time interpreting the world and not enough time reacting to it, you'll be lunch for something.

Yes, scientists do propose competing hypotheses and you use the same data to determine which one has both more explanatory power and more predicative power and is therefore more useful. That is sort of the entire point, to get as accurate a picture of what is 'real' as possible and have as many models that reflect that as possible.

The existence of illusions like the Ames window isnt an argument for why we should not be trying to come to scientific consensus - it is in fact why we started using the scientific method in the first place. Bias exists, our perceptions can be fooled, our monkey brains are imperfect, and so we must come at things from as many angles as possible to come as close as we can to the single truth of any one thing.

This is also using an effect called parallax mapping. We use this sort of illusionary device with textures in mods for the game Skyrim. 2D textures can give off the illusion that they're 3D (have depth) by using shadows and lighting in the proper places in the image, without the need for anamorphism.

One really critical thing I'm surprised wasn't mentioned about the South Africa test:
Viewing with one eye at a greater distance worked better because the parallax effect was less pronounced. The farther away from an object you are, the harder it is to decipher where the front and where the back is. The window will more likely appear to be oscillating when you can't notice any deformities as it rotates.
When looking with one eye, you remove depth perception, which also has a huge impact on the effect of this.

I've seen this, and other similar things, in person, and I've always been able to force myself to see the actual rotation by locking my visual focus onto the top corner of the tall side. By doing that, I can use depth perception to tell if that corner is moving toward or away from me. At least, I've always thought that was how I could tell; I was never really certain. It just, I dunno, felt like it.

...until now. I am now absolutely certain that that's how I do it. Since I can't get any true depth information from parallax and shifting focal length, I can't easily unsee the oscillation. It fooled my spatial perception in the video pretty consistently, with 2 exceptions:

One is a tiny part of the rotation of the small paper Ames window. That one isn't perfectly flat, so there is a point in its rotation where the small end is pointing almost directly at the camera where the curvature becomes visible and shatters the illusion every time. It reestablishes itself shortly thereafter, though, 100% of the time.

The other is the large plywood one, and only with some of the lighting conditions. Unsurprisingly it's only because that one is so thick. In some of the shots, the lighting and angle make it possible to focus visually on the top edge (and in particular the spots where the wires attach). That edge shouldn't be visible if the illusion were true, so it just barely allows me to see past the it. It's a lot more difficult than in-person examples, though, and there are shots where it still fools me.

Just as the Ames window illusion is re-enforced by our submersion into an environment full of rectangles, our persistent interpretation that mirrors reverse images left-right is re-enforced by our experience that 2D images always have a 3D body behind them.  A mirror image can be just as logically interpreted as an object which has the left/right orientation unchanged, but the near/far aspects reversed. This is also the basis for pseudoscopic illusions.

14:50 I just wanna say, its near infinite, not infinite. You can make adjustments around the room in all 360 deg for a starting vantage point, and all the different depths between those, and you can get a number of possibilities moving by approximately one atom at a time each. Its a lot of possibilities, sure, but its not infinite.

If I were a PH.D. Mathematician I could probably figure out exactly how many possibilities there are. Its probably something like P! (a) = n(a)/n(v) Where P! is the permutation sum and (a) is the number of atoms in the room and (v) is the number of different possible vantage points and (n) just stands for the (n)umber of times you use those positions.

The P! basically means P which is probability but is limited by the number of combinations that eliminates the one before it. For instance, if you have 5 colored marbles all the same color, they can be reorganized with each marble being in a different position and the number of combinations available. This would be represented as (P)5 and 5 is (n). However if they are all 5 different colored marbles, it would be (P!)5 where the order of the marbles matters. Theres only so many combinations of green marble being at the start that you can have before it starts to repeat itself. You don't have to go through the entire set again of Green Red Blue, theres only two possible combinations with that start at the end with the last two Yellow and Black marbles.

1,2,3,4,5
1,2,3,5,4
1,2,4,5,3
1,2,4,3,5
1,2,5,4,3
1,2,5,3,4
1,5,2,3,4
1,5,2,4,3
1,5,3,4,2
1,5,3,2,4
1,5,4,3,2
1,5,4,2,3

and so on I think you get the point. But take this times the number of atoms in a room divided by the P! of possible vantage points.

I'm at 2:47 in the video. The reason why the brain thinks that the cube is moving in the opposite direction has to do with the different heights of the trapezoid. The side the cube is attached to is the one with the short height, and opposite that side is the long height. The brain believes that short height must be further away from you, and conversely the long height must closest to you, despite the fact that the cube ought to theoretically break the brains expectations of what it should perceive. For some reason the brain perceives the dimensions of the trapezoid and processes them as either being closer or further away due to forced perspective ,and it also perceives the cube as a separate object. Supposition: could the brain be utilizing different neuronal networks to perceive the two objects and could those seemingly disparate perceptions be classing with one another causing the illusion ? Let's find out. Onward to the video!

I... can't say I like the conclusion to this. You fail to mention that when being prey to ambiguity in data, most of the time, all we need is data of another kind. Sure, in ancient Greece it was reasonable to wonder if the Sun went around the Earth, but it's not anymore. Now, we have many more datasets than just a visual observation of the Sun in the sky. Now, we know better.

Of course, until ambiguity is resolved, everybody might have a hypothesis about what's the most likely resolution and nobody should act high and mighty. But resolving abiguity is what science is: when there are multiple possible explanations, you look for a different dataset that will favor one or the other. When faced with a illusion, you don't have to sit there and wonder about "How's life mysterious", you get up and look from another angle until you figure out what's happening.

comment_by: Let's try to use real science, okay?
comment_text:
You mentioned the speed of light, implying that we have never measured the one way speed, and therefore cannot know it. We actually have resolved this one. We have measured the one way speed of light by observing supernova in very distant galaxies that we see multiple images of through gravitational lenses. We found a galaxy that had multiple images with some showing a supernova and others in which the star had not yet exploded. We were able to predict when the supernova would appear in the images by calculating the distances the light was travelling to form the various images and using the commonly accepted velocity of light, thus confirming that the light coming toward us travels at the same speed we measure in round trip experiments.

There is actually another, much simpler way to confirm the one way speed of light and that is to realize that the velocity of light in a vacuum is not a fundamental constant. The velocity of light in any medium, including its velocity in a vacuum, is a function of the permeability and permittivity of that medium. Since these values themselves are not direction dependent, they are a function of the medium itself at any given point, the velocity of light must necessarily also not be direction dependent. The previous inability to measure the one way speed is just an experiment in measuring things in general and has nothing to do with an inability to know that light always travels at a given velocity in any given medium with no regard to the direction it is traveling in.

the illusion works better the farther away it is viewed from (no need to try and move away from your screen though. the deciding factor in a video would be the cameras distance to the object). Cause increasing distance to an object reduces the amount of perspective distortion you percieve it with (just try and look at your face in a mirror from 3 feet away and then just a few inches, your face will look different). The experiment with 20 ft viewing distance shows more of an oscillating picture compared to the one with 10 ft. That's because the closer you are to the object the more a roll perspective distortion gets to play. If you get close enough you might even percieve the shorter vertical member of the window to be larger than the larger one, which of course can break the illusion. The closer you are, the greater the distortion, the better the understanding of its true proportions, the easier the illusion breaks

I'm stopping at the 6:33 mark, just after the result of the two test subject groups (carpentered and non-carpentered environments).
And I'm gonna suggest something, and see if my own hypothesis aligns with where this video analysis is going:

The result that gave a 90% successful illusion COVERED ONE EYE.
Now, this relates to my own experience, especially creating trompe l'oeil effects or anamorphic perspective illusions (like the ones created on sidewalks by artists like Julian Beever) - yes, I'm a geek when it comes to this subject, having been doing stereoscopic illusions with color pencils since I was a teen back in the 80's -.

When you are talking about stereoscopic illusions, it's about feeding the brain two separate signals. Whether it's via anaglyph filtering, like red/blue or red/green glasses, or by polarization or active filtering done by a quick shutter (like quickly closing each eye alternatively) which have to sync with an also shuttering video feed, which alternates between to separate perspectives of the same scene. It's all about fooling the brain into believing it's looking at a scene that has DEPTH. You are simulating the Z-axis (our 3d world has three main axis, which is X horizontal translation-displacement-, Y -vertical translation/displacement-, and Z which relates from a relative perspective -our viewpoint translation/displacement to and away from us).

However, when it comes to anamorphic perspective (you are literally painting the 3 dimensions on a bidimensional horizontal plain), you will not be able to fool the brain, which is using a stereoscopic view (two points of view - two eyes). The same could probably be said about this illusion, which will work fine on a VIDEO (which has no depth, unless you are doing the anaglyph or VR thing), it's actually a projection on a vertical bidimensional plain (you just have the X and Y axis - the Z is just assumed, but your eyes+brain don't see it - that's why 3D movies are cool, you get to feel the immersion of a 3d experience by having an actual Z-axis your eyes+brain can process).
IF you cover one eye, then you are getting the SINGLE LENS effect you get from filming whatever and displaying on a non-3d display.
The secret for a LIVE-VIEW of this illusion is for people to be farther away, and use ONLY one eye. Or to see it within a video, from a single lens perspective.

So now to continue watching this video, and let's see if it went in the same direction as my musings :)

We need more videos like this one. I have been involved in physics for ~20 years. I have an MS in it. The only way to get out of the current theoretical rut is to question things on a fundamental level.

I derived Relativity myself in high school (from what I later learned was the Lorentz/Bell perspective). I have been (usually) told it was wrong for all of those 20 years.

One of my physics professors (Professor Dalton) who specialized in Relativity saw how I thought about relativity and almost instantly said:

"Yep. That's right you can do it that way." I found out later that he thought the same way. There some physicists who do think that way.

However, in physics forums, for most professional physicists I've talked to, and in almost all physics documentaries (TV, YouTube, or books) only the orthodoxy view is ever discussed. Even Einstein in his papers said his view was a convention and to this day it remains as such. It's a legitimate way of thinking but not the only way to come up with the same math. Making better theories requires thinking outside the box. The orthodoxy erroneously limits how re can reconcile QM with Relativity.

Physicists see Relativity as "beautiful" and they often have an irrational hatred of people poking at that "beauty." Einstein is almost lifted to a level of deity in some circles in physics. He was a genius but still limited by what he could see like the rest of us.

No group is free from group think or irrational bias (even hard science).

What a beautiful demonstration of the virtual reality nature of our vision. What we see is a creation of the brain. The light stops at the retina, from there on the image is in the form of electrochemical impulses that the brain uses to construct a useful approximation of the outside world. During our evolutionary history, we never had to face drawings like that so the eye-brain complex uses its normal algorithms with the result that has little to do with reality. A fantastic experiment! Thank you!

Final part (and this is just my guess) : he completely destroy the flat earth mantra "I know/I'm sure because I see it" without even touching that argument.

Of course his sentence is more general and in those times the word "humility" is perfect.
Interesting how that humility combined with curiosity can be seen throughout history : in particular in philosophy from Cartesio to Hume and in science from Galileo onwards. Also the idea of illusion that evolved and became intertwined with the concept of bias especially while entering in the scientific discussion.

That humility I think is still present in science but also has been categorised more and we are still searching for a robust method that truly incorporates it in order to minimize illusions and biases

This reminds me of when you find really squashed and lopsided iterations within the projection of a Mandelbrot set.

I begin to percieve depth in this two dimensional.. object, (is it an object, a curve, idek) anyway, I think about how you could get an interesting side-on view of a Mandelbrot set through these squat representations, especially when you zoom past one where your focal point of the zoom is off to the side of the iteration.

also, funfact, off in the long arm of the set, the pointy bits, if you zoom in on the column, and the column is oriented horozontally, you begin to explore what I call the Forest of 'X's because these 'X' shaped structures regularly repeat in a sort of latice. So when you continue to zoom in through this columns the 'X's fly past you like you were running through this endless forest with a flat and unchanging horizon.

(even funner fact, this Forest of 'X's bears a striking resemblance to the distribution of X-rays when measured through X-ray crystallography... what a nifty coincidence... maybe the behavior of the equation in that position is similar to the functions related to x-ray movement and behavior. just a thought)

Years ago, here in Canada, both the Ontario Science Centre (Toronto) and the National Museum of Science and Technology (Ottawa) had "Ames" rooms.   They had very familiar, regular objects of what looked like "rectangular" shelves, cabinets, and checkered patterned floor tiles.  The floor is actually tilted, but our brains didn't perceive it that way.   I can vouch that the illusion was very powerful, as I physically struggled to stay "upright and level" based on erroneous visual clues.   Our brains are used to the "carpented environment", because rectangles are easy to build and offer efficient use of space and materials.  The Ames room furniture and floors look regular to the eyes, but were actually built entirely with crazy custom shapes and angles, since we can't fathom why anyone would go through the trouble to calculate, measure, and construct cabinetry were every single piece is a different, odd shape.

I've been blind in one eye my entire life. I've never had the sight of both eyes and then lost it. I was born with my left eye physically fine but neurologically cut off from my brain. As such I suspect I've adapted to judging depth through one eye better than most people.

You'd think I would have poor depth perception, but in practice I've repeatedly demonstrated better awareness of depth than all my friends. As an example, when playing 3D video games they were much more likely to misjudge the depth of a 3D environment, like a cliff's edge, when presented via the 2D surface of a TV screen than I was and would walk right off. I never would.

By contrast, I've never been able to see the images in 3D illusion books. So when I watch this video, all I see is the cutout rotating on the turntable. I cannot see the supposed "oscillating back and forth" illusion you're presenting. I dunno if only having one eye has anything to do with this particular illusion, but I can't perceive it.

I used to get discouraged at people with no background in science treating anything science related as unassailable truth.  More in more in recent years, I am seeing scientists view their own knowledge as unassailable truth. Almost nobody reminds of how little we really know, and how important humility is in the quest for knowledge.

As a human biologist it's so amazing to think how our brains process their environments. We humans have specific neurons (called grid cells) which are active in hexagonal patterns as we move around. We also have specific neurons which tell us when a person is looking at us or somewhere else. And in a quite funny experiment it was also shown that specific neurons are highly active when they hear the voice of Homer Simpson (would love to make a video about that myself). The fact that our brains fall for optical illusions just adds to their awesomeness!
